product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: So much better than print
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: If you‚Äôre considering this, and reading this review, you‚Äôre probably considering your first foray into Kindle reading. Good choice. A few things to note about this.The ads are not pop ups. I know some dead tree fans would have you believe, right in the middle of a tense scene, an ad will interrupt the page. That‚Äôs not how this works. What happens is, when you put the device in sleep mode, rather than say the cover or the portrait of a famous author, you see an ad. If you use the physical cover to turn on and off the device, you won‚Äôt see much if any of the ads.  And yes, you can dog ear a page.I have no idea why memes keep popping up to say you can‚Äôt. Actually, the things you can do with a print book that you can‚Äôt with a Kindle book are: Donate them to the library if the library starts taking books again, give used copies to a friend, sell used copies, have a bookmark accidentally fall out, and use them for, well, kindling. Kindle can do everything else. Things you can do on a Kindle and not a print book are: read in the dark, search for text, carry dozens of books in your pocket, create notes of virtually unlimited size (you run out of room in the margin of a print book), pick up a new book nearly anywhere, anytime, and instantly convert your entire library to large print.Most library systems can send any borrowed e-book directly to your Kindle. And your place and notes are stored in case you borrow the book again or buy a copy. You don‚Äôt get that with print.Amazon recently improved their send to Kindle features with a drag and drop web page that makes moving your own documents to the device extremely simple.This comes with a USB-C cable, but not a charger (aka wall wort) so if you don‚Äôt have one lying around (I think the expectation is most of us do) you will need to pick one up.16 gig might not sound like a lot, but most books fall under 2K.  I‚Äôve seen public libraries (I‚Äôm looking at you, Florida) with fewer books than this can hold. Audible eats the memory a bit more, but I find this to be more than enough.You don‚Äôt get cellular connectivity with this, but that‚Äôs only with the premium Oasis line now. Scribe even missed out on that. I find it convenient, but I understand wifi is ubiquitous enough these days it‚Äôs not a big deal for most users. I have an annoying habit of finishing a book on the crosstown bus, then needing the next in the series. Yes, the cell phone tether works. No, that‚Äôs not as convenient as built-in cellular.It has fewer LEDs than most, but that‚Äôs not a big deal. Four lets you read in the dark. The scribe has 35. Guys, it‚Äôs an e-reader, not a disco, no one needs that many separate lights on that small a device. The absence of a warm light and auto adjusting lights are a bigger issue here. The warm light makes a big difference when you‚Äôre reading before bed.It doesn‚Äôt have the waterproofing, which I thought was a bigger deal when that first came out, but in all the time since I‚Äôve yet to (knock wood) get a Kindle wet. It‚Äôs a nice to have, not a have to have.The size can throw people at first. The screen approximates two things ‚Äì an index card turned portrait and a mass market paperback page. The occasional ‚Äúghosting‚Äù mirrors the see-through element of the cheaper mass market paperbacks, except on the device it refreshes quickly, and the ghosting goes away.There were some studies done that suggest memory is improved from reading from print rather than e-book. I want to point out a few issues and cite my own experience. First, all the studies I could find cite pop ups and other distractions as the primary issue. That is, the test is on a general-purpose tablet, not a single purpose e-reader. When they either do a study on an actual e-reader or compare with pop ups on the tablet vs someone coming over just as often and tossing brochures on their print book I‚Äôll believe it. Unless all factors are equal, the study is inherently flawed. To my experience, my ability to absorb and either use the information (if it‚Äôs non-fiction) or retain it over time (if it‚Äôs fiction) is nearly identical in both, with the slight advantage of the e-book being able to search back in the text for prior information. It drives me nuts when a quote resurfaces in a print book, and I can‚Äôt find the prior mention again. Or when I need to find a code snippet in a shelf full of computer books rather than just search on device and have it in seconds.So, if you‚Äôre comfortable with the mass market paperback format, the size, the quality, then this is a huge step up. If you want to lay your hands on information quickly, then this is a huge step up.If you want portability, then this is a huge step up. I just had to help an elderly woman move into assisted living and the loss of space cost her nearly all of her much-loved library. I find it comforting that nearly all of mine fits in my purse. No more culling the library for space, then finding you need to buy a new copy. If you delete an e-book from your Kindle, you can download it again for free. I remember, in the dark days before the Kindle was invented, being stuck on a flight from Arizona to New York with nothing to read but the most misogynistic, worst written mystery novel I‚Äôd ever encountered. If I had a Kindle, I‚Äôd have had at least a dozen better choices at hand, not to mention rereads.The downside here is twofold. First, Dune and The Great Gatsby look the same size on the reader, so it‚Äôs hard to eyeball that one is a super-fast read and the other a meaty novel. It‚Äôs also a little too easy to build up a massive TBR pile, given it takes no physical space, the device memory is ample, and Amazon keeps offering free books to Prime members every month, sometimes more than one, and a crazy number of deeply discounted books Prime or not.If you are concerned about the environment, then this is a matter of economics of scale. On the last study I checked, the magic number was 20. At 20 books the manufacture and transport impact of the e-reader ties the impact of manufacturing and transporting print books. At 21 and beyond, the e-reader has almost no further impact as compared to the printing and transporting of physical books. E-readers have boasted substantial improvements in reducing their carbon footprint since that study, but I can find no more recent information. Even at 20, the worst number, it‚Äôs clear that e-readers are a pure win for the environment.It‚Äôs a great device. If you want to go with this one as the entry level, you won‚Äôt be disappointed.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: I love this!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: It took me a long time to convince myself to buy a kindle or nook or any other electronic reading device. I always felt like it was a silly spend when I have hardcopy books, and kindle on my phone.I happened to walk by a display for this at Target a couple of weeks ago and it really caught my attention. It felt so easy on my eyes to read, and I liked that it was small and portable. I still couldn't convince myself..I read every day so my mind kept naturally going back to it. I talked myself into by looking at it as a time and learning investment üòÜ I've stopped paying attention to social media a while back and cut down TV time so I can focus on something more productive. I like the idea that this is only for reading. There's not texts on it or social media, or notifications or apps to get distracted. I love that about this. I really like being able to silence my phone at night and read in the dark. Or read in a park and leave my phone in the car.If you're having a hard time justifying it, just go for it. You'll use it!

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: TY Kindle Tech support ... Correcting my previous review 6" and 6.8" models
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I was so frustrated.  I love the 6" Paperwhite for me...my hands are smaller and reading with the 6" is easier to hold.  Meanwhile, my husband loves his 6.8" paperwhite.  Both are 11th generation, did not come with the correct plug for the faster charging station, I must retract my comment about them not coming with charging cords.  They did.  I needed to pull out the brown cardboard bit inside the package to see the cord at the bottom. I didn't know that, but feel dumb anyway.  The frustration was increased by an intermittent issue with our Network.  All our devices showed we were consistently online...but the Paperwhite would not connect.  Intermittent issues are always difficult, we seemed to get on,one for everything except Kindle.  Our provider finally saw the failure happen not on our router but in network after many hours over 2 days of trying to explain.  I want to thank Annie and Maggie, at Kindle Tech Support for their patience and their help, for sticking it out with me through trying to figure this out.  We Love our Kindle Paperwhite... have had several generations over the years...this one is my favorite.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Read anytime anywhere!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: If you just love to read and are not a print purest when it comes to your books, get this thing.I love to read, but I absolutely loathe trying to read a printed book when there is not excellent lighting. I don't know about you, but I cannot stand it when there is a shadow over half of the page or I can't get just the right angle towards the lamp to be able to see the page correctly. I have tried reading lights that clip to my book and hang around my neck but I have never been able to get it right. I felt weird spending a lot of money on a device just to read on but I am so happy that I did.I freaking love this thing. I can read in any lighting and the page is perfectly clear. My wife loves it also because when I stay up late reading in the bed I can turn off all of the lights and not disturb her. The backlight is great. I can read outside and it looks the same as it does inside. Very little glare even in direct sunlight. I also really like that I can have the exact same text size and font no matter what book I am currently reading.The size of this kindle is great because I can slide it in my back pocket if I am somewhere out and about. I can hold it in one hand without feeling like I am holding a giant tablet that I might drop at any moment. Obviously, the touch screen and refresh rate can be a little annoying at times because they seem so out of date, but when all I am doing is reading I do not mind it 99% of the time.Finally, I love that I can turn off/on the page number and I can see how long (in minutes) it may take me to read a chapter. I hate having to close my book in the middle of a chapter because I run out of time. Now that I can see an estimate of how long it will take me to read a chapter I can gage whether I need to start the next chapter or go ahead and set the book down until later.The ads are not bothersome at all so don't worry that they may ruin the kindle in some way. They are not pop ups and are only displayed when you are not reading.If you just love to read and are not a print purest when it comes to your books, get this thing.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Great Upgrade but could be a little smaller
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I love when Amazon continues to support their kindle e-ink devices. And with every new e-ink release, I always pick them up. They are such a niche product that doesn‚Äôt get enough credit. They are perfect devices that remind you to be more productive in life and help you disconnect and read!The Amazon kindle 2022 version comes with a USB C port and it is long overdue! Now I can finally pack away my micro usb cables for good! The device charges quickly and the battery life is great.The operating system is the same from previous devices but with some new quality of life improvements including a dark mode. I never knew I needed dark mode and I love it.I think the biggest critique I have for this kindle is the screen size. I wish that Amazon would release a smaller e-Ink device that‚Äôs the size of an iPhone. I love the idea of a smaller, more pocket sized kindle that can fit alongside my iPhone.I feel like Amazon is getting really close to an even better device and I hope they consider it. I truly think that a smaller e-ink screen the size of an iPhone would do great.Another suggestion I have for Amazon is to look at the PlayDate device. The playdate is an amazing device. Seriously amazing. I love how animated, and pretty the playdate is and how small it is too.Imagine if the next kindle functioned like a playdate and had more animated menus and sounds and book titles were more pretty. I think there‚Äôs so much possibility there.Anyway thanks for reading my review!

title: Love it

text: I admit, I love to read.  I love the feel of a book in my hand.  That being said I have 405 books on my kindle right now and never will need to build more bookshelves.I set the pages up for white print on a dark background, easier on the eyes.  I can make the print bigger or smaller.I can go crazy and order every one of the Longmire series books, then came 2 more different series.  It's sort of like binge-watching Netflix, except I get to read it.  For me there is something about reading, over hearing, that makes my heart sing, after all I've been reading for 70 years now.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Perfect size for portability
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I really love the size and weight of this kindle. I have the Oasis which I have used for years now, but I bought this one because I wanted to have a kindle I could easily throw in a bag or a coat pocket. It‚Äôs perfect for that, but it‚Äôs actually much more pleasant to hold while reading than the Oasis is. That‚Äôs while using the clear case on it. It‚Äôs a little slippery and hard to grip without the case. I imagine the case with a cover would make it even easier to hold. I definitely recommend this Kindle over the Oasis and possibly the Paperwhite (which I haven‚Äôt tried) because it‚Äôs so comfortable to hold for hours at a time. I would go without the premium features of the other Kindles I mentioned just to have a Kindle that is this lightweight and small. I can only imagine how much I would love it if this little Kindle did come with those features. It would be absolutely perfect. As it is, it‚Äôs a delight.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: A device with a single purpose: reading
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Everyone has a smartphone these days, so at this point the Kindle is for one very particular audience: people who want to read a lot of books, and read them with a minimum of distractions.  With this version, Amazon has refined the Kindle to the point where it's just about ideal for this purpose.  I've owned several previous Kindles, including an early Paperwhite, and currently own a couple of iPads, an iPhone, and a MacBook.  For the purposes of long, immersive reading sessions, this Kindle is my best option.  The battery life is long enough so that even with constant reading you only have to recharge once or twice a week (you can extend that by turning off wireless).  The Kindle also has by far the best screen for immersive reading: it's sharp and clear, with many options for different lighting conditions ranging from bright sunlight (Kindles leave tablets in the dust as far as bright-sun reading is concerned) to pitch black (the dark mode format is ideal for this).  You can choose whether to read with a vertical orientation or a horizontal one -- and this option of a horizontal orientation allows you (among other things) to read poetry on a Kindle without imposing premature line breaks.  This Kindle is also extremely light and easy to hold for hours on end (my iPad mini is too heavy for that).  And as with all Kindles, you can adjust the type size and font so that reading is comfortable for you - I love paper books, I really do, but I need bigger type.In a way, though, what's best about this Kindle is what it doesn't have.  You can't read your email.  You can't go on social media.  Amazon's Kindle browser is perpetually "experimental" -- good!  I pick up the Kindle when I want to read books, not when I want to lose my afternoon down an internet rabbit hole.  That said, you do get just enough of the internet to assist in your reading.  From within any book you can look up unfamiliar names/places on Wikipedia, and there's a great built-in dictionary too.  (You can download dictionaries for any language you read, and set them as your default in settings).  But apart from those features, the internet might as well be on Mars.  Fine by me. If I want to look at videos of puppies or lose my temper about politics,  I have my phone (and several other machines, unfortunately).  When I look at my Kindle, I can feel my blood pressure go down.  More to the point, I can hide my phone under a cat and read books for hours and hours.That might not be your idea of an ideal afternoon.  If it is, and you know who you are, this Kindle is pretty inexpensive and much lighter and easier to carry than tablets or physical books.  It allows you to carry thousands of books around with you and then sit and read them without distractions.  It's limited in its other functions - and that's exactly what makes it ideal.As you can probably tell from the above review, I have the patience of a gnat when it comes to content I don't want to see, and for that reason I opted for the ad-free version.  This allows me to have the lock screen be the cover of the current book I'm reading, which is extremely endearing.  That said, the version with ads does not insert ads into your books; they're not obtrusive in that way.  So you can definitely save a few bucks by getting the version with ads - it won't mess with your reading experience.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: pleasantly surprised
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Had an OLD kindle which I loved. But it was starting to hang up and the battery life was significantly diminished. Considered every kindle offered and chose the simpliest as the one most like what I had. I the back lighting is superior and plenty bright. I confess to frustration navigating pages at times. The touch screen is so sensitive it can be over-zealous and advance too far. I'm not a fan of the home page but think I need to spend a littl more time setting it up for me. One recommendation - DO NOT pay to avoid ads! Bless the person who wrote a review and said this as I was ready to pay for no ads. They are NOT intrusive and only appear on the home screen until it wakes up - about 5 seconds. Absolutely not a problem. Recommended.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Love it!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I love this kindle! I only recently got into reading as a hobby so I decided to purchase the base model and it‚Äôs a great device for a fair price. I tend to read for an hour or more most days a week and find myself charging it every 10-14 days. Great battery life. The low light/dark mode option is great for reading in bed at night so if you have someone sharing the bed with you it won‚Äôt disturb them. I haven‚Äôt used it in the bright sunlight yet so I can‚Äôt exactly speak to how legible it is in the sunlight but I‚Äôm sure it would be fine, as I keep the brightness level anywhere from 3-5 and there‚Äôs a lot more room to go up.Love the dictionary, Wikipedia, and translation features for unfamiliar words. Also like how it tells you when a lot of people have highlighted a sentence ‚Äî makes you focus up because it‚Äôs probably significant!All in all I‚Äôm thrilled with my purchase. It‚Äôs a simple yet fantastic e-reader.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: I thought I would miss actual books until now
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 25, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I LOVE THIS THING. Everyone asks me why I bought this even though I have a phone and and iPad and I could just get the kindle app and read it like that. But I could never see the screen on either when I‚Äôm outside and I can always read the screen on the kindle. I‚Äôm also the kind of person that LOVES paper and I really didn‚Äôt think I would like the kindle because I love seeing my progress with the pages, BUT honestly I love it because the screen looks like a paper and it tells me how far along I am in my books. I was recently reading an 800 page book and it was just too heavy to read and I ended up just buying it on the kindle and I ended up reading that in 2-3 weeks because it was just that easy! I LOVE THIS SO MUCH! Give it a try! Even if you love the feeling of paper like I did, I promise you won‚Äôt regret it!

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Only one complaint; well, two
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 13, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: My Kindle is slightly wider than my phone, which makes it easier to read.  The screen gray scale can also be adjusted so it's easier on my eyes.First complaint: the thing is so light and thin, it really needs a cover/case. Mine kept trying to hide in my recliner. I got a cover so I wouldn't hear a crunch sound as my recliner chewed on my Kindle.Second, and more important, complaint: I can do a custom sort in the Kindle app on my android phone. The Kindle device can only sort by title or publication date. What's up with that?When an author has been writing a series for years, there are prequels, sequels, spinoffs, prequels to spinoffs. And collections of short stories! They are not gifted with alphabetic-ordered titles, nor in a neat and tidy publication order.I want to be able to sort books on my Kindle device the same way I sort in the app.It's not a deal breaker. I love my Kindle and in no way regret getting it. But...custom sort order pleeeeze?

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: 10/10 Excellent device for reading and here‚Äôs why(:
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 4, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I was looking to read more books this year and reading on my iPad and iPhone was doing the job but always felt the strain on my eyes after I was done and kept getting distracted by notifications and TikTok videos so I decided to give the kindle a try so I could focus more on the books I was trying to read more of, so I decided to go with this one as I figured it was the perfect size to keep in my bag without taking up much space and let me tell you I am glad I made the purchase because this device is truly perfect. I don‚Äôt strain my eyes, it‚Äôs light enough to hold for long periods of time, has many useful features that you would expect from having wifi, bluetooth (helpful for listening to audiobooks), being backlit for some night reading, to also being able help you define words that you may not know the meaning of. I am glad I got my kindle and if you are trying to read books without purchasing physical books all the time and don‚Äôt want to get distracted by tiktok and notifications on your other devices like me, then I do believe this is a really great option to consider giving a try as well.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: I can adjust it to font and size I want
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 12, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: There are many reasons this is my 6th kindle.  I still have 4 otheres.  About every two years I update my reader. Over the years the ease of use and sizing has made preferable over the Kindle white.  While it does not have many of the features the other kindles have it is priced just right  Reasons I love this Kindle.1) size and weight2) back ground color.  I have problems with white back lights and so the light gray and black lettering is easier on my eyes than the kindle white allowing me to settle in for a long read in the evening3) durability.  I use mine a lot and the only problems I have had are d/t my dropping it.  Which I do more than I would like.4) you have access to Kindle unlimited which I use enought to make it worth the monthy fee.There is one glitch in the last two kindles, and that is sometimes the touch page turns back a page instead of forward.  Still waiting for Kindle to fix that glitch.  When I have the time I will do a complete reset to see if that fixes it.I have not used the audible feature as I am one who liked to read vs listen and so I cannot comment on that.  It has other features that I do not use.  Any other deficits are related to how the author formates their book. My friend publishes on Kindle and she has a lot of control over formatting.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Favorite Kindle Yet, Highly Recommend
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 27, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: After having five kindle readers, I‚Äôm very happy to have upgraded from my last paper white.  It was a few years old but worked well except for one very specific upgraded feature I wanted; inverse display.  The inverse display on the new model is excellent and helps even more with low light reading in a dark room.  Even though this model doesn‚Äôt have as many LEDs for lighting as the new paper white, the display really looks great, I don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm missing anything.  It gets as bright or dark as I want.  The change in size of the device is nice too, smaller overall while maintaining the screen size.  And personally I prefer the traditional screen for the e ink display, the flush front display on the newest paper white might be nice for being water proof but I didn‚Äôt want another device that had the feel of reading off a tablet.  Before buying I read some reviews that were unhappy with a ‚Äúcheap feel‚Äù like it would be easy to break.  I disagree, I use the same travel zip case I have been for my other kindles, and the feel of the device is fine, no concerns at all.  I‚Äôm pretty happy reading on the new kindle.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: My latest Kindle
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 24, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I had not bought a Kindle in many years and I was going on a cruise, so I needed reading material.  this is a good Kindle but it is very very sensitive;  the lightest touch turns it on and you really have to watch it otherwise you drain your battery.  While on the cruise the Kindle, all of a sudden froze, and I had to look on the internet on how  to unfreeze it.  Other than that and the above pesky problem of being sensitive, I am happy with the kindle the main reason being that because of my poor eyesight, I can make the font large which you cannot do on print books

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Loved Kindle 11th gen over Kindle PW 11th gen
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 30, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I honestly had a hard time deciding between this Kindle basic 11th gen and the Kindle Paperwhite 11th gen (PW). I own an older PW released in 2015 which I absolutely love but I wanted to finally try the Audible so I decided to upgrade. I tested both this Kindle Basic 11th gen and the Kindle PW 11th gen for about 2 weeks, used both everyday. I'm still a little on the fence but I finally settled with Kindle (basic) 11th gen because it met my basic needs.  Here are my observations which led me to pick the basic model.The first good thing about this basic Kindle is that the screen is more matte than the new PW. I could not get past the reflections that I see on the screen of the new PW when there is a window or light behind me when I'm reading. I do not have that problem with my old PW. I also prefer the lightness and the size of the Kindle basic, although the cheap feel of the plastic build bothered me at first. It slides more easily off my hand than the PW and it scratches easily but I fixed that by putting a back cover on the Kindle basic. The build of the new PW felt a lot sturdier though.I don't mind that the Kindle basic doesn't have the warm light feature that the new PW have although I'd probably use it when reading at night IF the basic had it. The warm light only works if you have the backlight on. I don't mind that the basic is not waterproof unlike the new PW. I don't soak in the tub and I rarely get in the pool to purposely read so I'm fine with it. I also like that the Kindle basic has an actual frame around the screen unlike the flushed screen on the new PW which makes me feel like I'm reading from a tablet, imagine the glare on top of that.Both of them get the slight screen burns when I scroll up or down, not too bad so far. Both of their bluetooth function (BT) worked great for Audible, but the BT coverage on the basic actually went just a few feet farther than the PW before it started cutting out. I did notice that the battery went down faster on the basic but it's probably because I left the BT "ON" all the time. I did get the "application error" message once on each reader at some point but it didn't seem to affect anything. Neither of them became glitchy although I'm not sure why I got the error message.They both worked good in dark mode. The glitch that other people mentioned when turning the page happened on both new PW and the basic. The dark mode lights up briefly (but quickly) before displaying the next page. This can be fixed by turning off the Page Refresh from the Reading Options menu.There are other features on new PW that I don't mind NOT having only because I could not get past the glare, size, heaviness, and the flushed frame of the PW. The Kindle basic met my basic needs without the cons, "my cons", of the PW :)  In my opinion, the Kindle basic is easier to carry because it's super lightweight, fits in my purse or pocket in my jacket easily, and I was able to adjust to the smaller screen size in no time. Overall, I think it would just really be a matter of preference between the two.Edited: I added 2 more pics to show the back cover with popsocket on my Kindle basic! :)

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: I love it
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Picture with my hand for scale (from palm to finger is roughly 7 inches)This is my first ever kindle, as I wanted to start reading more again and have no room for physical books and tend to get stuck on them. This one was the cheapest so I went with it and absolutely a worthwhile purchase.Firstly, setup was incredibly easy and you get 4 months free of unlimited which has so many books and big titles for free (hunger games, harry potter, lotr, etc)I absolutely love the size, I was worried about it being too small but as someone with longish hands it is SO comfortable to hold and fits perfectly in my hand, put a popsocket on the back and you're golden. Tapping to turn the page is comfortable and overall just a nice experience.I was worried about the screen being too small but it is perfect and you can read on it very easily. This screen has absolutely no glare, we sell PW at my job and that screen has a bit of a sheen to it compared to this one. It looks and feels like paper. I can not believe I can read at night with no eye strain.The battery life is decent, definitely not weeks to a month (depends on how much you read) 2 hours of reading drains 10% of battery. Which is plenty for most and it charges insanely fast. Unless you're planning to be reading somewhere with no access to a charge port for 24+ hours straight with no breaks, you'll be set.Books are SO much cheaper on this. I used to collect physical books, it was a small collection (like 40-50) and sadly it's somewhat expensive and requires a lot of space. A book I was looking into is $18 for a physical and was only $6 on the kindle. So you'll save space and money (also saving time and the papercuts from page flipping)I still love my physical books, but this will make it so much easier for me to be able to read and I've been more inclined to pick up my kindle to read vs scroll on my phone. I highly recommend this kindle.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Buyer beware!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I order an ad fee version of my new kindle device. Upon receiving device I discovered it still contained ads. After a few phone calls to Amazon customer service, I was told they forgot to unlock the device to enable the ad free version to my new kindle. The customer service agent said they would unlock it on their end and after a simple restart of my device, I would no longer be receiving ads. After restarting my device several times I still had the ads. The customer service agent said that my device was defective, and that they would be mailing me out a replacement. I received the replacement device today and it is not a new ‚Äúad free‚Äù Kindle, but instead a ‚Äúrefurbished‚Äù item. I don‚Äôt understand why they would send me a refurbished item when I purchased a new device which was by their classification ‚Äúdefective.‚Äù The customer service agent I spoke with said this is their policy. I told them I would just keep my original Kindle with ads and send back their refurbished item. I was told they could not send me a shipping label for their ‚Äúrefurbished‚Äù item! This policy makes zero sense! I bought a brand new ad free Kindle less than six weeks ago. Why they felt this was a fair exchange is beyond me! I asked for a refund for the fee I paid to remove ads, but was told that was not an option. I am beyond baffled!!!

text: I bought this Used for $77, with Amazon being listed as the seller.  The description mentioned there may be some cosmetic damage, but nope.  Aside from some major fingerprints on the screen it looked brand new after I cleaned it up.  I bought the official case recommended by Amazon at checkout in black to cover any damage it may have.  It's a bit expensive at $25, but it really does look incredibly sharp.I just purchased the Paperwhite 11th gen, 6.8" screen last year (my 10th Kindle it turns out) and have been reading with it like a maniac since.  Now...I get this little baby and can see a drastic difference in size.  It took some getting used to.In my opinion, if you are going to be reading for hours at a time at home, I would spend the extra $40 and get the larger Paperwhite.  It really is an enjoyable tool for serious reading.  For me, this compact little paperback size Kindle Basic (it's not a Paperwhite) is perfect for short burst reading sessions at the many doctor's offices and clinics I go to for my wife.  It fits perfectly in my small backpack and is much lighter to lug around than my usual Paperwhite.  If, for some reason buying it used bites me in the butt and it dies on me, I would definitely buy another one at full price, I like it that much.

text: ¬†I had this kindle for less than 3 months. It was always in its denim matched case. Today I decided to remove the case and notice what I thought was a hair. After careful inspection in the light I noticed it wasn‚Äôt a hair but hairline cracks along the backside on the sides of the kindle. I‚Äôm not sure if they were always there and I‚Äôm just now noticing or what. I only use the kindle at home around the house or before bed. And I am always very careful with it.  I‚Äôve never dropped it so I‚Äôm not sure how the cracks got there. I called Amazon and they are sending me a replacement and the process was a breeze. I‚Äôm glad they stand behind their products. If I look to getting a new version in the future I might go with the one with a metal back again that is stronger. The reason I chose this one was the size and weight of the device. I noticed the plastic is quite cheaply made though. For now, I‚Äôll be content with the replacement but will keep this experience with this basic kindle in mind for the future purchase of a new one.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Yeah....it's good
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: First off, I didn't buy this just so I could own one. I bought it because I needed something dedicated to accessing and reading books. That being said, I prefer to focus on how well it meets that need. In a phrase, it does.1. The battery life I agree is good. I have been using it every day for more than a week now, for maybe a total of 4ish hours per day, and it is now at 15% battery life. I imagine that it could last me another 3 days or so before being depleted.2. The screen is responsive enough and also easy on the eyes, both in dark and in light. Pretty much like looking at a printed book page. Yes, I have observed sometimes the flickering that is mentioned by others when flipping pages, but that doesn't bother me.3. It is light and small enough to fit in the pocket of most trousers that I wear, shorts even, yet has enough screen real estate and zoom capabilities that gives comfortable reading without having to excessively flip pages.4. It has just one button, quite simple, so no extra pressing and clicking needed.5. I can charge it with my other chargers, so I don't even need to use the cable that came with it, because my phone uses the same thing.6. I had decided against spending extra to remove the lock screen ads, and I am satisfied that I did. The ads are not intrusive, as they only appear when the screen is locked, which means that you are not using the device anyway. I have also glanced at some of the ads and went "hmmmm.....maybe I should check that out....". So yes it think it may be of some benefit to have it rather than not.7. I had wanted to subscribe to the Unlimited option but strangely it says that it is not available in my region...well...okay. I'll buy what I need anyway.Overall, I'd say about this device, so far so good....

I‚Äôd recommend a case for it because it‚Äôs pretty hard to hold without one with it being so thin. product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: The Last/Least Shall Be First
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I am a long-time Kindle user, and own and use an Oasis, a Paperwhite Signature Edition, and the new Basic.I gotta say, I honestly believe the Basic is my favorite. It's the one I reach for, it's the one I want with me.The Oasis is slick, with the buttons and all, but I never could bond with it. That grippy ledge... It's neat, but you lose that if you use a cover, and if you don't use a cover, the device feels cold and hard, because it is made of metal, which feels cold and hard. (And the battery life is *bad*, compared to other Kindles.)The Paperwhite Sig has all the great features... and it really is a great device. I recommend it. Really everything you could want in an eReader. Really.  (Battery life is amazing!)But... but...After a few years with the Oasis and some months with the new Paperwhite Sig, I realized how much I missed the form factor of the early ones. And now the Basic has USB-C and 300 ppi. Those count a lot. I like the warm light on the PW Sig, but I don't miss it when I don't have it. Waterproof sounds good in theory, but even after 10 (?) years of reading everywhere, including the bath tub, it hasn't been a thing. Battery life on the Basic is just fine, and it charges fast.The thing is, the Basic has the perfect form factor. So light to hold, so easy to slip into a pocket. Even at home, where portability isn't an issue, and even sitting in my armchair (as opposed to being in bed), where weight isn't an issue, the Basic is the one I reach for.You would think a bigger screen would always make for a better reading experience... but no. This is highly subjective, but there's just something *cozy* about reading on a little Kindle like the Basic version(s). (If you need a big screen ‚Äî which you do with some books ‚Äî you can use your computer or iPad.)Obviously Amazon should just start making the Paperwhite in multiple sizes, with all the features (give the little one the warm light and waterproofiness), but meanwhile, even without those, I think this is the best one.Save your money, buy the cheapest one, and be happy. You will bond with it.(And get the Amazon fabric case.)

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Love the size
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: The size is perfect.  I haven't had to buy another Kindle since my original paperwhite whenever that first came out (several years ago anyway).  That one still worked perfectly fine and I wouldn't even have gotten this one except the software was becoming outdated and I was unable to download some things easily anymore.  I wasn't sure if I wanted to go with more of the bells and whistles of some of the more expensive versions, but I really wanted this size and I'm happy I got this one (I'm not used to the bells and whistles with my kindle anyway).  The only feature I really change daily is the one-touch day to night/night to day lighting button.  Love that!  My only complaint is that the touch screen is very, very sensitive (as was my other paperwhite).  All I have to do is hover my finger over the screen and the page turns, so I get a lot of double page turns and am constantly having to go back a page - annoying to be sure.  I wish there was a way to adjust that sensitivity.  Otherwise it's great.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Comparing the Kindle (2022) to the Paperwhite (2021)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Biggest difference between the Kindle (2022) and the Paperwhite (2021) is the price -- the Paperwhite is $40 more for half the storage.The screen looks the same to me, albeit 0.8 inches diagonally bigger for the Paperwhite. They both are excellent in full sun and have the same screen resolution. The Paperwhite has some additional LEDs that allow users to switch to a "warm" light that I personally never use and don't like.The price differential comes mainly in the screen size, the battery and the quality of the case. The Kindle is advertised as running for 6 weeks (half an hour a day) on a charge and the Paperwhite for 10 weeks. The Kindle also charges faster, leading me to the conclusion that its battery is smaller. The Paperwhite screen is flush with the case, as one would expect from a mobile phone. The Kindle has a screen inset in a plastic frame, giving a clear impression of a cheaper device. The result is that the Kindle is not rated for water resistance, while the Paperwhite is IPX8.  But I didn't buy my Kindle for how it feels but rather how it operates, and in that respect I really don't see much difference in the Kindle and the Paperwhite. They seem to work the same, the screens are equally readable, and both have more storage than I use and run longer than I need them to on a charge.I found both devices sluggish to operate and underpowered. This is especially obvious to anyone who has used the Kindle app on their phone or PC. I thought the user interface was not very responsive and not well designed. Both are very annoying in that they turn off automatically after a relatively short inaction period and I could find no setting to change the value -- power saving is either on or off. This is a real pain when I use my Kindle to follow a recipe when I'm cooking.So I rated the Kindle (2022) highly and a far better value than the Paperwhite (2021). The only good reason I can think of for getting the Paperwhite is if you like to read in the rain. With that said, Amazon occasionally offers deep discounts on the Paperwhite, so that's something to look out for.Hints: Put your contact information on a card between the Kindle and whatever your case you buy. Don't store any private information on a Kindle. Don't waste your money on an "ad free" version. All that does is remove ads from the "lock screen" that you never see except when turning the device on. Either way, once on, it will try to sell you stuff.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 1, 2023

text: I decided to try a Kindle for just reading such as Paper White Kindle series for hopefully better battery life than what I experienced with the Kindle Fire series. Now, don't get me wrong the Kindle Fire series is fine if you're looking for a tablet first with the added benefit of reading books. Needless to say, this Kindle has checked all of the boxes for me because I just wanted an eReader to read my books only that had great battery life. This is it. It's the first Kindle with USB-C for charging. It definitely lasts for several weeks before you need to charge it again. I read each night before bed.The price doesn't break the bank. Not only can you read books but you can also listen to Audible audio books on this too.I'd like to see the ability to change the screen to display warmer at night on a future version. I'm happy with my purchase and think those looking for an eReader would as well.

text: Have owned the previous version of the basic kindle for a couple of years now and loved it. The only things I disliked were the lack of yellow light or dark mode, and the micro usb charging. This one addresses both of those issues and that was enough for me to pull the trigger, plus you get a sweet discount and a gift card for trading in your old kindle. The touchscreen on this one is equally as bad as the last one, and battery life seems worse than before. I read about 30 minutes a day and find my self having to charge every 10 days or so. However, the usb c charging is super convenient and this one has a dark mode which makes reading at night in the dark a joy. I also love the new blue color! My old one was white and always got dirty. Pro tip: buy a pop socket for it!! It will make it a lot more comfortable to hold.

title: My first.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I just got into the ebook reading trend with eink readers. So this is the first eReader I get but I do have a supernote, which got me enjoying eink tablets a lot. I've never seen kindles in person and didn't realize how small they are. My supernote is bigger so going to this took me some time to adjust. I do like it so much even the size because I can easily take it with me. Adjusting the font and size helped a lot personally and suggest it. I really like that it's basically a smaller and cheaper paperwhite and it has more storage than the basic paperwhite. I have been reading more and thanks to the free 3 month unlimited I haven't paid for any books yet. I also love that it was already connected to my Amazon account. If you buy it for someone else remember to mark it as a gift so your account won't be connected to it. I really love the price compared to my supernote that was over $300 of course my supernote is multipurpose and I use it for note taking. This Kindle is great battery life is good as well especially if you keep it on airplane mode. I can spend hours on this device reading. I don't like the ads so in future purchases I will be getting without ads. I had the ads taken out. I have no issues with it, it is as good as other eink readers and tablets. The ghosting is something normal that happens in all eink readers and tablets. I changed the settings so it can refresh with every turn page and that helped so much. One thing I would suggest is making them in white. I prefer white over blue or black.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Nicely  portable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: This is a great little portable device. I bought it for the beach,  but haven't tried it there yet. My prior experience is just reading books on my tablet. Adds are only on lockup screen. Nothing pops up while you read. Don't pay for no adds. It's unnecessary.  I like this reader, but have to say, it's really tiny. Not much bigger than my phone. If you're using this as primary reader, you might not be happy, though you would probably get used to it. I like it's portability size. Easy to tuck in purse and not heavy. A selling point for this is the long battry life. I think it said weeks. Sorry... thats not true. If youre reading all day like I do, you'll only get a couple days from the battery. The only big concerns I have is that it doesn't seem to easily download books on its own. It seems much faster if I buy book on phone or tablet and just download by clicking when new book icon appears on the reader. Things I miss compared to my tablet is that you cannot choose a color when highlighting. I  use color highlights to mean different things. Other thing I miss is that, while it will look up words (dictionary), it doesn't have a translate option for foreign words. I really miss that function.All in all, it's a great device for the price.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Surprisingly Great
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I think I‚Äôve bought approximately 10 million Kindles over the last decade or so, starting with generation 2 with the keyboard. I‚Äôve loved all of them, but I just keep trying different ones and then selling other ones, always just trying to figure out how many I want to keep around, and which ones.My favorite is probably still my Oasis from a couple years ago. I love the big screen, the big holding area on the side, and the page turning buttons. But sometimes I just want something a little smaller and lighter that I can stick in my pocket and that I can not worry about damaging too much because of the expense of getting a new one.This new basic Kindle is a great size and feel. It is so light, so nice and small, and just feels really cozy and pleasant in your hand. And even though I generally like big bezels for the sake of the convenience of holding things without touching the screen, I find that this shrunken Kindle is really pleasant to hold in a few different ways even though it has smaller bezels than past Kindles.I could see someone thinking that it‚Äôs pointless to use this if you have the Kindle app on your phone, but many of us still appreciate the reading experience on the Kindle, mainly because it‚Äôs just for reading. No matter how much I‚Äôm into a book, if I‚Äôm reading on my phone I find that I‚Äôm just constantly switching to other apps and doing other things. And E-ink is still just a slightly nicer reading experience, especially in sunlight or other bright lights. I don‚Äôt really know about eye strain that people talk about with phones. I never get strain from my phone as far as I can tell. I think phones are perfectly pleasant for reading most of the time. So for me it‚Äôs really just about the pull and distraction of all the other things you can do with the phone.And the screen is beautiful, now that the basic Kindle has a higher resolution. Not having as many lights as the Paperwhite or Oasis doesn‚Äôt really matter to me. The screen lights up just fine for my purposes.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black

I used to keep a cell Kindle  in my car and one at home. That way they always synced and when I stopped someplace in read and then came back to the house so I didn‚Äôt have to run out to the car and sync, the Kindle.  Otherwise awesome device.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Hello shelf space
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: The shelf space you‚Äôll save alone makes this a wise purchase.  Not to mention Kindle versions are WAY cheaper than print versions.  I‚Äôve been snagging up books on my shopping lists for anywhere from 20 cents to a dollar.  This is my first time purchasing a Kindle, or E-reader period.  My first impression out of the box was that it was kinda small, but after using it, I‚Äôve realized the size is pretty much equivalent to most paperback books. Anything bigger might be too big to comfortably grip for long periods.  It‚Äôs extremely light also, so holding it for a couple of hours won‚Äôt be a struggle.  The screen is basic black and white like previous Kindles.  I initially bumped the screen brightness up to 18% because it seemed dim, but that drained the battery significantly.  After researching (googling) the problem, the suggested brightness level is 10-12%.  After switching it, I haven‚Äôt noticed the loss of charge like before.  Navigation is pretty easy ; tapping the bottom or top of the screen brings up most of what you‚Äôll need to use the device.  I would suggest installing a software update asap after getting your device, I immediately noticed performance improvement after doing so.  You have to download the update and add it to the Kindle while it‚Äôs plugged into a computer, then install the update through the Kindle.  Reading books on this thing is a relief to your eyeballs after staring at phones and tablets.  It‚Äôs very similar to reading a paper copy of a book.  I do miss the feeling of accomplishment when turning a page in a book, but I guess a screen tap will have to do.  I highly suggest getting the canvas cover offered with the Kindle for $25.99.  It‚Äôs a little pricy for a case, but it‚Äôs high quality, looks good, and magnetic so it snaps to the back while reading so as to not be bothersome.  You also get 4 months of Kindle Unlimited free, which is usually $10 a month.  I say go for it.

title: Exactly what I wanted in an ebook reader
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I bought the ad supported version because I honestly don't really care about the ads all that much, they're something I can just skip over and I'm not too picky myself about what shows on my sleep/lockscreen. Now if you're someone who would prefer to have the cover of the book you are reading on the screen, I would spend the extra 20 dollars for the ad free version, but if you're like me then save that $20 and buy the ad supported version, it shows you other books you can buy from the Kindle store and that's the only ads I have seen in the month I have own this Kindle. But features wise, this Kindle was exactly what I was looking for: easy to use, not too many extra features, it's really easy to get my library books that I borrow from Libby onto my Kindle and the battery life is really excellent and I read A Lot. It's exactly what it advertises: Basic. If you're looking for something that's more flashy or has more than just the basic features I would go for something else, but this Kindle is a really good first-time e-reader for someone who may have never had one before. I can honestly say having this e-reader has made a marked improvement on my ability to read ebooks, it was hard on my eyes to read for hours on end on my phone and the e-reader is much more gentle on my eyes.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: I love it, I love it, I love it.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 3, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I'm a long-time Kindle user. The first model I owned was the fourth generation $79 model back from 2011, then I had the 2015 Kindle Paperwhite and owned that for several years. I decided to upgrade to the latest 2022 basic model, and I have to say that this is my favorite Kindle I've owned to date.Initially I was going to settle on one of the newer Paperwhite models for their larger, 6.8" display but I didn't really like the material that the screen was made out of. It felt too cheap and looked too glossy, and the flushed screen design didn't appeal to me so I brought it back. It felt too much like a small tablet and not like a simple e-reader like my older Paperwhite did. I then considered getting the previous basic Kindle model from last year but the 168 DPI screen didn't appeal to me, so I chose this one instead once I found out about it.And let me just say that for the record, this is absolutely worth every dollar. It's essentially a basic entry-level Kindle model, with upgraded features that you would have seen on an older Paperwhite such as the 300 DPI screen resolution, and also USB-C charging which is fantastic because that doesn't break as easily, and the text looks sharp and crisp. The responsiveness is just about flawless and battery life is as good as it's always been, especially if your backlight isn't too bright and you have airplane mode on. While the screen size is standard, the body of the device is trimmed down to give it extra portability factor, making it perfect to fit in small bags or purses.If you think about it, this Kindle model is kind of like a mini Paperwhite. You might not have extra features such as a slightly bigger display and backlight color temperature settings, but I don't ask for too much out of a simple e-reader and the upgrades from previous generation models is so worth it.One thing that I would absolutely recommend is to buy a case for this thing as soon as you get it, or have it shipped with a case. I'm using the official fabric cover case and it's incredibly sleek and keeps my device from getting dirty or scratched up.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: A Comfortable and Convenient E-Reader with the Power of a Library in Your Pocket
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 13, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: My history of using Kindles goes back to 2009, when I bought my first Kindle. I bought my first Kindle Paperwhite in 2014. Although I have bought every generation of the Paperwhite ever since, I found that I did most of my ebook reading on my laptop, cell phone, or desktop. I'm not sure why that was, but I think it was because it was convenient.When Kindle Basic was issued, I didn't give it much thought; I thought of it as a cheaper version of the Paperwhite, not quite as good but suitable for those who couldn't afford a more expensive e-reader. Yet one of my anxieties about investing so much in Kindle e-books over the years- I now have over 5,000- is that I dreaded having to shell out about $200 for each new reading device any time I lost one, or it became unusable. $200 each time seemed too much to pay.On top of that, I found that I wasn't using the device as much anyway because I couldn't slip it into my pocket like a mass-market paperback. When I wanted to sit down and read, why would I use my Paperwhite when I could just as easily -- and more comfortably -- use my laptop?  The cell phone seemed to be a quicker and better option when I was on the go.The Kindle Basic is lighter, making it more convenient to use. It is smaller, making it more fun and easier to carry with me.The Kindle Basic is not unreasonably small, like a cell phone, and it is not as clunky as a laptop. It is just the right size, like a small paperback, only much lighter and thinner and good for reading in the dark or outside on a windy day and indoors anytime. The text is clear and sharp, like a more expensive Kindle. Best of all, it is affordable, so I don't have to worry about replacing it. In a nutshell: the Kindle Basic makes reading easier and more pleasurable than the more expensive models.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black

text: I‚Äôve had a few Kindles over the years. All have been great. I love that they finally added dark mode to this new Kindle. For me, it‚Äôs so much easier on my eyes. I love to read while in bed or in a dark room so the darker screen is so much better than the bright white. My 2 complaints about this Kindle are that every so often.. maybe every 5-10 page turns. It will page ahead 2 pages instead of 1. Also every so often it will for a second flash the white screen when changing pages if it‚Äôs on dark mode. If these two minor flaws were fixed, I‚Äôd say that this is a near perfect Kindle. The battery lasts forever! I read sometimes all day long and it barely puts a dent in the battery percentage.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: POS
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: This is one of the worst products I have ever purchased on Amazon (I buy a LOT - the Amazon kids tablet was even worse, though). My grandson likes playing on my phone, so I bought this to read on while he's on the phone. First, to "sync" to my phone and do a quick setup, I had to upgrade the Kindle app on my phone. Which then got rid of my ability to purchase books on my phone due to "play store rules". Horribly inconvenient and on top of it, the sync never worked (after trying for over 30 minutes). I finally just did the setup myself.Now I can buy books on this device, so if I'm reading on my phone, I have to open this device, hope it syncs to the last page, do the buy on the kindle. BUT then if I want to continue reading on the kindle, I have to X out of that screen, go back to the last book, reopen the store, and hope it lets me read the book. It has never once just let me click the read now button and go forward.I will say most of the time opening a book on one device and then the other, it syncs to the latest page read, which is fantastic!! Sometimes it doesn't and it's a massive pain to find the right page. And the kindle will give you the option to jump forward, but then the same screen stays up and gives you the option to jump back where you were. Took me a minute to realize what was happening, but now I know!Clicking pages forward or backwards is hit or miss - sometimes it goes forward when I tap on the right, sometimes back, sometimes it skips 3 or 4 pages. Sometimes it works ok, but OMG is it a frustrating device. I was reading on a Nook in 2010 that worked better than this!!  The technology has been there for over a decade, why is this so crappy? And the nook was cheaper than this thing is!! I switched to kindle for the free book subscription.I paid the extra for the no ads, which supposedly puts the cover of the book you're reading on the lock screen. Nope, it just puts random designs, but they stay there between books and just randomly change. They are never the cover of the book I'm reading, which is absolutely fine, but don't lie about what we're buying.This is extremely light weight, almost disconcertingly so, which is a plus. I had to stop reading paper due to the pain in my hands. It doesn't fit much on a page for my aging eyes (I'm only in my 40s but losing my near sightedness). I was expecting more to a page than on my phone, but it's really about the same size just wider and shorter. Battery life is ok - I've had about 3 weeks and already had to charge it once and it's at 30% again. I read for max 2 hours a day on this device and the rest of the time on the phone.So, overall, it does what I bought it for, badly, but it does it. I do NOT recommend this product, especially for the price. I'm a little shocked at how poorly Amazon produced this product.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Loved this Kindle but it "died" within 4 months
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I've had Kindles ever since the first one came out. I don't like reading books on my iPad. I read a lot and don't like accumulating hardback books. Kindles are perfect for me. I've upgraded my devices every few years. Although it's not considered an upgrade, this model was my favorite of all:  loved the size, the weight, the screen (very easy to read), the battery life. Loved everything about it. What's bad is that it "died" within 4 months of getting it.I never had a problem with all my other Kindles. I hope the problem is not a design flaw and that it will last as long as my others. If it doesn't "die" I strongly recommend this model.It was disappointing when it "died" and I have explained what happened at the end of this review. It's probably too much detail but it is what it is.I was in the middle of a book when it "died", so first, I ordered another one just like this one (reduced from $100 to $75) because I didn't want to wait the time it would take, once I found the right person to speak with at Amazon, for them to either fix this broken one or for them to send me a new one after mailing it back to them.I called Amazons Kindle help line to get an answer to this problem. They were great to work with and are crediting the purchase, and I am mailing the broken one back. I am satisfied with how the issue was resolved. The order I placed for a new one, and paid for, will be delivered tomorrow.Exactly what went wrong:The problem started when I couldn't find it - I left it (the new blue one) on the treadmill on the 2nd floor. Because I couldn't find it, I got an old black Kindle out, charged it, downloaded the book I was reading, and was finishing the book when my husband found the blue Kindle on the treadmill. I turned the blue one on - no problem - and began scrolling to the page where I left off on the old black one. Then everything on the screen went black. The green light was still on, but when I pressed the on-off button, the green light stayed on for only 2 seconds and the screen remained black. I plugged it in thinking it needed a charge. When plugged in, after about 10 minutes, the "sleep" screen came on. I unplugged it, pushed the on-off button, and the screen went black. I pressed the on-off button again and the green light was on for about 2 seconds. The screen remained black. I went through this process numerous times: sleep screen came on after about 5 or 10 minutes when it was left alone or plugged in, the green light remained on during this time, when I pressed the on-off button the screen turned black again. Every time I pressed the on-off button, the green light would go off in 2 seconds. I kept going through this process numerous times and the result was the same. That's when I ordered a new one and decided to figure out how and who to contact at Amazon the next day.Again, I never had a problem with all the other Kindles. This is my favorite for the reasons I have already mentioned. I hope the problem is not a design flaw and that it will last as long as my others. If it doesn't "die" again, I strongly recommend this model.

title: Poor comfort, great backlight.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on April 3, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I've been using a kindle since the beginning, owning plenty over the years. The only reason I bought this was for the backlight, which really is great and doesn't hurt the eyes.This version is super light and fairly slippery, making it uncomfortable to hold. Gone is that slightly non slip backing. Definitely a form over function design. A small bevel is not ideal for comfort.The swipe vs button for page changing means if you are holding it with your left hand, you have to move your right hand from resting to turn the page. It's just one of those things that a physical button makes for a more enjoyable experience.The touch only can also be a pain when wanting to use the dictionary. Sometimes it will turn the page, several times I don't know what I did but it took me several chapters ahead.Seems like it was designed not by an avid kindle user.I'll get a case which I think will help for holding. Again the backlight is great.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 23, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: As one would hope it would be. It makes reading fiction and non-ficiton a breeze; quite fast and it can fit a ton of books.I also read manga on it, which my old Kindle could not. This is fine, though I might've done better with a larger screen. Small lettering can be hard to read, requiring either zooming in (a little slow) or turning up the screen brightness. Between the brightness and presumably the added data load of comics, the battery life for me is a few days instead of weeks I remember the store page advertising. But it's still more than good enough.In general Kindle paperwhites are a delight to read on, and this is no exception.

text: We purchased the 2022 kindle paper white for my husband after his 2018 version quit charging. The new version is smaller and feels the tiniest bit lighter as well. All basic functions are the same, but the fonts are more crisp and clean on the new version. My husband also pointed out that unlike the 2018 version which had the bezel under the screen so the front was completely smooth, the new version has a raised bezel around the screen and the bezel isn‚Äôt quite so smooth. I think it helps you hold onto it a little better and it makes your page turn motion not need to be so pronounced. I have small hands and I prefer the feel of the newer version‚Ä¶ may have to trade in my 2018 version for an upgrade as well üòÅ.

text: I got the Tens Unit due to recent lower back pain. After seeing a similar instrument used at my chiropractor I decided to get one on my own for home care.They supply you with 2 sizes of pads with multiple pads. The first time you use a new pad the adhesive that stick to your skin is very strong. It's fairly simple to use, you just take of the clear protective coating and apply to the area.There are 3 different modes to choose from, I just use the one named "MASS". After about 20-30 mins of use on my lower back, I can definitely feel a difference, my back muscles feel a bit looser and worked on, similar to a deep tissue back massage.

It's fast too, with quick page turns and no long waits for pages to load when browsing the Kindle store.It's compact and very lightweight, making it great to take with you. I had debated whether to purchase the previous Kindle basic model, but I'm so glad I waited for the upgrade, it is well worth the price, which is still very reasonable.If you are on the fence about this one, I would highly recommend you give it a try. I think you will be as pleased with it as I am. It's a great Kindle, at a great price point.

title: Amazing upgrade from Paperwhite 2014.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Coming from the Paperwhite 2014, the biggest upgrade for me is the sharper text, battery life and speed. The screen is the same size at 6 inches as my Paperwhite 2014. I did purchase the Paperwhite Signature and decided to return it. The weight and size were bugging me on the Paperwhite Signature. Also, there seemed to be more glaring on the Paperwhite than this basic Kindle. There‚Äôs no warm light but I have no issues without it. If I‚Äôm tired, no amount of blue or green or strobing lights will keep me awake. If the Paperwhite Signature were the same size and weight as this Kindle, I would have kept the Signature instead. I read a lot and I have no issues with this edition of the Kindle. My only grip with the Kindle (all editions), there is no text to speech like on the Kindle app. The Accessibility text to speech means it will read everything on the screen and makes navigation awkward and difficult. They need to implement it on the next software update cause no matter how old I am, they‚Äôre bound to be some words that I can‚Äôt pronounce properly.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Amazon‚Äôs best Kindle for the money!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I never thought I‚Äôd love a Kindle this much, especially given that it‚Äôs Amazon‚Äôs entry level model.  But for that 99 dollars you get 300ppi e-ink display, USB-C charging, 16GB of storage, and battery life that beats my Kindle Oasis.  Plus I love the denim blue color of it.  This Kindle is so compact and light, it really does fit nicely in your pocket even with a case on it.  The Kindle is literally the size of a paperback book that can hold thousands of books with its generous storage.  I have 600 books on it and I have not even put a dent in my storage space.  The user interface is snappy and it is as fast as the new Paperwhite and as the most current Oasis.  The only disadvantages this Kindle has over more expensive models is no warm light feature and it is not water resistant like its pricier siblings.  Still, though, this is THE Kindle to buy and for its price point you are getting a lot of great features in a compact travel friendly device that keeps going and going.  This is a MUST have Kindle.  10 out of 10.
