product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Prefer my Fire HD
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: NOTE FOLLOW UP EDIT AFTER BELOW REVIEWI wanted to like this device after reading the reviews.  I dropped my Fire HD 8 (10th gen) and the screen cracked down the middle but it is still very readable.  It is a fairly heavy device with the kickstand cover on it, so poked around to see what I could replace it with‚Äîsince I really don‚Äôt tap into all of its computing power and apps.  I was intrigued by a lighter device that would also be readable outdoors in the sun.  I‚Äôm afraid, however, that this Kindle Basic is just too basic.  My primary source of reading material is the library. Overdrive was my download platform, and then my library switched to Libby. You cannot download either of these apps to the 11th gen Basic. In fact, you cannot download any apps, and the web browsing experience is dreadful. If latency and stuttering bother you, you will hate this.  So in order to download from the library you have to use another device and then point that device to this device to download the book. Not a huge hassle, but having all of your interactivity on a single device is where I want to be. Regarding the performance of the Basic:  the page turns are definitely not as quick and crisp as the Fire. It is slower, and there is a tad bit of latency.  If you read at night next to your significant other, the ‚ÄúDark Mode‚Äù on this device is more gray than it is black. Definitely inferior to the blacks that Fire offers.  If you enjoy seeing the the full color covers of the books you read‚Äîyou won‚Äôt be doing that here.  Finally, the size is just too small for my liking. Why not just read on your phone if this is the size you are looking for?  Lastly, I don‚Äôt trust all of the reviews boasting about battery life. Mine arrived at 53%, and by the time I was done with Amazon Kindle Support on the phone to confirm the web and app limitations the battery was down to 43% after also running a book download experiment by installing the Libby app on my phone and pointing the download at the new Basic. The Basic is now back in its shipping box with the return label attached and ready for a drop off at UPS.********Follow up:I have received my new Fire 7 (see picture above) and have achieved all of the goals I set out to accomplish.  The photo compares it to my Fire 8 HD (with a vertically cracked screen that you can‚Äôt really see).  Initially I had the 8HD for traveling and downloading movies. I don‚Äôt do much traveling anymore, but if I want to download content, I figured I can just use my MacBook with Retina screen for that.  And besides, all of the reviews for the Fire 7 say it is hard to tell that there is no HD since it is a small screen experience that you are only 2-3 feet away from. I don‚Äôt disagree. The great news is that without HD there is not as much processing speed required, so you end up with a MUCH lighter devise. As an ebook reader the performance mirrors the 8HD: crisp precise page turns, etc.  As you can see in the photo, the white background, however, is a little warmer, which I don‚Äôt mind at all. The mori√© effect on the Fire 7 pic is just a byproduct of the photo, and it does not look distorted in real life.  The weight of the Fire 7 and the cover with kickstand and hand strap that I have ordered is just over 15oz, which is just under 1 lb.‚Äîthe weight of the average hardback.  Perfect.  Smaller and more manageable, lighter, excellent performance, the ability to download apps, a good web browser, ability to download content up to 16GB, and MUCH CHEAPER than the Basic Kindle.  The only thing that Basic Kindle will do better is allow you to read in direct sunlight‚Äîwhich I rarely do anyway since I am usually active when in direct sunlight.  5 stars for the Kindle Fire 7.

text: I‚Äôve always used the kindle mobile app, but recently I‚Äôve been getting bad headaches from reading in the dark at night. We have a small apartment with a baby, and leaving the light on isn‚Äôt an option. No matter how much I dimmed my phone screen, my eyes were still strained. I decided to give the kindle a try since it was supposed to be easier on your eyes. I wasn‚Äôt sure that I‚Äôd like it. I‚Äôm used to using the continuous scroll option in the kindle app. Surprisingly to me, I actually really like it. It‚Äôs super lightweight compared to my phone, it doesn‚Äôt hurt my eyes, and I can read better outside as well. I do miss the continuous scroll, and wish that was an option for kindle devices, but it‚Äôs a small sacrifice for not getting headaches.

title: Best entry level Kindle yet!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 22, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I have the current Paperwhite 2021 and the 2018 version.  This new Kindle is really comparable to the 2018 version without being waterproof.  I think the build is sleek.  It may not be premium but it's nice.  If you plan to use a case you aren't going to notice anyway. The text seems crisper with sunken bezel screen vs. the flush screen of the Paperwhite.  This Kindle is really all that is needed to have good reading experience since it has dark mode for night time reading.  The 6 inch screen is more than adequate for reading.  It only has 4 leds lights, but without the extra layer of plastic/glass on the screen the background of the screen seems about as bright as the Paperwhite which has more lights, when used at the same brightness level. Unless you read in the  bath you don't really need the waterproofing.  I read outside sometimes and the previous basic Kindle has gotten raindrops on it with no issue's. I think the compact design makes it very portable and easy to hold comfortably.  If you plan to take this to work or school it's a great choice.

text: I have used kindle and other readers since the original Kindle keyboard.  I have loved them all.  This one (11th generation) is great. The backlight makes it easy to read in bed at night, or in a dim living room while your spouse watches television.The only complaint I have is common to all but a few models of eReader, regardless of make. That is the lack of buttons for page turning.  The original kindle keyboard had them and I loved it.  Please bring them back.

title: Some steps forward, some steps back
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Compared to my 8th generation kindle.  It's smaller, and it -seems- noticeably lighter even though the specs says it's very marginally lighter.  Screen seems sharper, and backlight seems useful (although i will never use it).  The on-off button works better (the button on my old one was always finnicky), but I do notice that it takes more pressure to engage the touch screen.  Buttons have to be pressed more firmly, and I can't turn the page with my fingernail anymore, it needs a swipe that is pressure behind it.  Otherwise the experience is almost exactly the same.  Has the same cr@ppy software update that removed the super-useful BACK button.  All in all an improvement, but the touchscreen was a surprise.

text: This kindle has been such a blessing to me! It is easy to carry and read, it is not heavy in my purse, and it‚Äôs easy to hold. Though I have not yet learned all the details of operating this little cutie, it serves me well wherever I travel.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Great First E-Reader
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: While I'm not very experienced with E-Readers, I think this one comes in just right. Though I will probably get a paperwhite sometime for home. This will certainly stay my work and travel E-Reader. First of all, charging with USB-C is wonderful, as almost everything is USB-C these days, and not needing to dig for a micro is very nice. It's super lightweight as well, especially if you have just the Kindle itself. I got a case for it as I don't like damaging my products in any way, and I read before bed, so it's not always out of the question for it to get dropped.It does, however, have it's downsides. When bringing the device to a higher brightness, it has an odd hue to it. But, I can get past that for the price. When you put a case on it, it can get fairly heavy. Though, compared to a book, it's still like a feather. And, the power button on the bottom is a little odd, but, I think I do prefer it there. It's just a bit odd to get used to at first.With all of this said, this Kindle is great for either a first E-Reader, a device for a child to read on, or a travel reader. As it fits in most pockets and certainly any handbag, it's an incredible way to make sure you're entertained wherever you go.I highly recommend for anyone looking for something to read on the go!

title: Back to basics
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I do not generally write reviews, but wanted to offer my two cents. I originally had the 2019 Kindle Paper white with the 6in screen, and decided to upgrade. I ordered the new paper white signature but did not realize it had grown in size from the model I had. I tried to live with the new paper white but perhaps I‚Äôm just too basic lol. The size was too large and did not give me that cozy feeling while reading.On to the 2022 kindle, I ordered this to see if I would like the size and LOVE IT! It‚Äôs so simple and easy to hold, no frills and basic, much the same as a traditional paper book would be. The screen in my opinion reads more like an actual book than the paper white. I appreciate the simplicity of it, as I feel most things these days go overboard with features.My only gripe would be the feel. I saw another review mention it also, the plastic feels a bit underwhelming. I do wish it would have the same texture as the other models. However this is something that will just take getting acclimated.All the models have their perspective buyers and you really cannot go wrong with any, it‚Äôs simply up to personal taste. However those who want an inexpensive and smaller kindle should definitely try this. Good luck and happy reading!

title: USB-C, compact size, and functional Wi-Fi
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 21, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: My 2020 Kindle kept dropping the Wi-Fi signal--and we have a strong signal everywhere in the house. Made me nuts, since it was very difficult to update content. The new Kindle has not dropped the Wi-Fi connection once. The slightly smaller form factor is not a problem: readable screen area is about the same as with the previous version, and it's conveniently the same height as my phone, so a bit easier to carry. And it finally uses a USB-C fast charging cable, so I don't have to worry about keeping multiple USB cables around. Also, getting the Kindle in blue rather than black makes it easier to see where the power switch and charge ports are, and that's a blessing for my 50+ eyes. Otherwise, same great features I'm used to with Kindle.

text: I absolutely love this kindle. I would have purchased the basic years ago if it weren‚Äôt for the 167 ppi but since they updated it to 300 ppi I went and purchased this one. I bought the kindle paperwhite 2021 and have had it for a little over a year. I do love the upgraded paperwhite but I wish they had kept it on the smaller size. It‚Äôs just too bulky and awkward to read and hold, and with the significantly smaller bezels extremely hard to find a good finger placement.I will miss a few things the paperwhite offers over the basic like warm light, smoothe page transition, the ‚Äúpage‚Äù turn animation just to name a few. But for the light weight and size I was willing to sacrifice a few of these things and just hope that a few of these will be added in later generations.The ‚Äúglitchiness‚Äù isn‚Äôt an issue. Anyone who knows and is familiar with eink is aware that this is just the trait of eink technology and using front lighting vs back lighting, and not having a constant refresh rate that tablets and phones have.Highly recommend.

options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: For the price this is nice. You can‚Äôt compare it to the Paperwhite, it feels cheaper, doesn‚Äôt have a flat front, isn‚Äôt as bright (specs say it has 4 LEDs as opposed to Paperwhite‚Äôs 17) so that should be expected. It isn‚Äôt waterproof and it‚Äôs a bit slower. However, it‚Äôs a good entry level kindle, good for someone like me who wants it to fit in the purse (very lightweight) and who won‚Äôt feel as completely devastated if it‚Äôs lost or stolen.  It‚Äôs easier to hold as it‚Äôs lighter and smaller.Three issues I have. You can‚Äôt make the home screen fonts larger (you can, of course, increase fonts in the book) and secondly, the packaging was atrocious. It was in its small, non-padded box in an envelope. The box was torn and crushed. The kindle seems ok so far but it was in no way being protected.Last of all, there is no option to do away with the ads. To pay for something that uses the device to continuously send me ads is frustrating.

title: Glitchy and not very touch sensitive
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I‚Äôll start off with what I like about this kindle. For one I love the small size. It‚Äôs a little bigger than the size of my hand and feels cozy to read with. But what I have noticed after using it for the last few weeks is that when I tap to turn the page, it sometimes doesn‚Äôt register that I‚Äôve tapped the screen and I have to tap it a little harder to get the page to turn. I wish it were just a little more sensitive to touch. I have also noticed that sometimes if I tap the screen to turn the page, it will turn two or three pages ahead and that has happened quite a few times. I then need to go back and find my spot in the book which is a bit irritating. In some ways, I wish I had bought the oasis so that these problems could have been avoided with the buttons that kindle has. Lastly I have noticed when reading that occasionally the whole screen will change from dark mode to day mode/vice versa quickly when I turn the page. That‚Äôs a little irritating at night when I have it on dark mode and it will flash bright for a second when I don‚Äôt expect it. Over all though I do like this kindle. I like how small it is and how I can easily take it in my purse or bag anywhere. I just wish these little glitches didn‚Äôt happen so often. I agree with most reviewers saying that it‚Äôs a good starter kindle because of the price, size, and how light weight it is.

text: In 2010 I bought my first Kindle Reader. It was a revelation at the time. Since then, there has been an explosion of technological advances in electronics. Advances I had hoped would be incorporated into the new Kindle which I purchased last year. Unfortunately, I see very little of those technological advances in this most recent incarnation of the Kindle Reader. Despite the advertised 300 ppi screen for easy reading, the whites are still dingy gray and the blacks are a wimpy charcoal. Scrolling and page turning are both stodgy. Visually, it's basically the same Kindle from a decade ago. Still readable but disappointing.

text: I‚Äôm not one to review unless the product is great, so here I am. I had the basic 2019 Kindle until last month. It did almost everything I wanted, besides dark mode and it was getting to be a bit slow. So I decided to upgrade to this kindle because it‚Äôs twice the storage, dark mode and clearer text. One of the best decisions I‚Äôve made yet. I have read close to 4 books on this thing and it‚Äôs only at 53%. I do keep it on airplane mode when I‚Äôm not buying from the store, but this is still incredibly impressive. The only thing I don‚Äôt like is the power button on the bottom, I feel like I have to hold it weird. But other than that, if you‚Äôre thinking of buying a basic ereader that isn‚Äôt fancy and does the job, this is an incredible choice.

text: So I traded in my kindle I bought last year for this new model and loving it so far. text: I didn‚Äôt like that they decided to make the Paperwhites bulkier.  So decided to go with this.  Overall is has most of what I wanted.  It‚Äôs a little more compact than my last Paperwhite (and much smaller than the new ones).  I like the pin lock option.I‚Äôve taken two stars off because this is not water proof, and they don‚Äôt offer a waterproof option.I do a lot of reading around water, so this not being water proof is a real annoyance.  I‚Äôve got to throw it in a water proof case and of course remember to bring a water proof case if I‚Äôm around water.  I don‚Äôt get why they decided not to offer a waterproof version.  Someone who wants a smaller more portable Kindle is probably going to carry it in places where it can get wet (as opposed to a larger one that probably never leaves the house).  You‚Äôd think if they were choosing whether to make a bulky kindle waterproof or a smaller one, they‚Äôd make it the smaller one.

text: When I first opened the package, I was shocked at how light and cheap the kindle felt. It barely even feels like an electronic, just a piece of plastic. There is absolutely no color on it so all the book covers you will see are black, grey, and white which is a little disappointing, but technically not a big deal. But after a couple hours when the screen started to be more reactive, and I figured out how to rent library books on here, I realized that even though I was determined to return it at first, it does allow me to read books which is why I got it. My disappointment was probably because I expected it to be like an iPad, which it absolutely is not.

text: I‚Äôve had almost every version of the Kindle since they were first available in 2007. Over the years they have had more features but they have also grown heavier and larger, with wider or taller shapes. I thought a long time about about trying the basic Kindle but their lower weight and better font quality convinced me to take a chance with one. I‚Äôm so glad I did. The size and weight are great and the print quality is fine. I haven‚Äôt had problems with uneven lighting or page turns, although some people have reported those issues with almost every other version of the reader. The battery life is good, although the new Paperwhite‚Äôs lasts longer.

options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: The screen reads like printed paper.  The navigability of this Kindle is much easier than my first Kindle with the little buttons.  The 1500 books I've loaded take up just 2 Gb of memory, and I can find a book within seconds using the special navigational screens--all touch-screen movements.  The best feature is the compact size of this Kindle: I can pop it in my coat pocket.  It weighs about the same as my smart phone.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Finally! An affordable e-ink Kindle
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 10, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I have been waiting a decade (or more) for Amazon to create a decent modern replacement for my *original* kindle that is actually affordable. Here it is at long last!This machine is light-weight , has excellent battery life, Is easy to hold (no more thumb pain), has Wi-Fi, a high definition grey scale e-ink display, backlight for low-light reading, excellent memory capacity, and a touch screen.After 15 years we finally have a proper updated version of the original Kindle with all the modern amenities. My original Kindle still works as well as it did when I bought it, so if this one lasts half as long it will be well worth the reasonable price for this model.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Rather nice upgrade for anyone with an older paperwhite that lags when advancing pages. This one is completely instantaneous, and can go sleep to reading in 2 seconds.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: New and improved at an OK price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 18, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I've used my 2019 10th-gen Kindle to pieces. Loved it! But time for a fresher one: cracks and sticky page-turn. Also 167 ppi was not helping my aging eyes.This 2022 release reader looks better right away. Better contrast!! Slightly better lighting (I think they save the best LED-clusters for the hi-price model). And 300ppi means less fuzzy text. It is about a millimeter smaller all around so it fits in the same pockets. I never filled-up the old one so this one is "infinite" for books (texts; art-books may eat more space).This also has the new fits-both-ways USB connector and it is IN THE CENTER!! (The 2019 was just a little off-center, enough so I could not find it in the dark, even before one-way-up.)If you have an older low-line Kindle getting tired, DO buy this one.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: So cute!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 13, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Without Lockscreen Ads
text: First of all, I really wish Amazon would just do away with the ‚Äúbasic‚Äù option, and make this the ‚ÄúPaperwhite Mini‚Äù. Give it all the same features, plus some new color options, and I would say it‚Äôs perfect!!However, as that‚Äôs not reality, I will say they‚Äôve made some great updates to this device - USB-C charging, improved battery life, dark mode, etc.I just bought the paperwhite 2021 model last year, but I think I may use both devices. This one for errands, travel, maybe longer reading sessions as it‚Äôs lighter. I may keep the Paperwhite for reading in the bath, or by the pool, and may use it to house library ebooks as they come in (since they always come in at the same time!) and keep it permanently on airplane mode. TBD though!Love the portability, and the hardshell exterior (shows way less fingerprints). Overall great  little device. Just wish they gave it all the Paperwhite features and it would be perfect.

options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I meant to order the new Paperwhite, but I am thrilled with this one. It is smaller and lighter but the screen size is the same as the 2021 Paperwhite. It's great to have a USB-C connector and the beveled edge overcomes the issue I had with turning pages by accident on the Paperwhite with no screen-to-frame discernible border. I have used just about every Nook and Kindle product ever manufactured and this is by far the best one. Battery life may be overstated a bit, I received this on Sunday and on Tuesday I'm at 64% so it probably won't last for "several weeks" as advertised, but I can take a weekend trip without worrying about running out of power. I don't think I've ever been quite as ecstatic about an e-reader.

text: The screen leaves burn from the previous image. You can see where the book cover "Midnight Sun" has a burn of my book cover of "Fright Night". (Don't judge my vampire reading!!!) Also "Sunshine" has a burn of the hair and eyes  from the cover of "Written in Red". This burn isn't an issue when reading regular text, but if you were to read a graphic novel with it, this is a potential problem.The screen from my 7th generation Kindle Paperwhite has sharper images too... Right is the Paperwhite 7th generation. The left is the new Kindle 2022 release. Even though both have 300ppi, the contrast is better on the Paperwhite. Both were lit to 15.I do like the fact that the new Kindle is lighter and smaller, so reading for an extended amount of time causes less wrist strain. (Wow that sounds spoiled.) However, it feels flimsy, so I worry about its durability if I were to take it on the go.Update 10/17 - Amazon sent me a replacement. It still has bad screen burn, so it wasn't just my unit. It must just be the nature of the item. If you are planning to buy this item, just know that there will be an issue with images.

title: 1950 calculator technology

options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Item is not as described I thought this was supposed to be the newest technology of KindleThis is a very antiquated calculator version of Kindle.It is amazing to me that Amazon is a company has been so successful with this being their flagship product & then investing such little time and energy.....& into making this technology something more affordable and advanced.Imagine a world where there was a virus or some sort of pandemic and we all had to learn from our tools that we bought from Amazonand we bought these Kindle ebook w/out apps & with the expectation of learning not deforesting the world in order to feed our appetite for reading.After spending more money than a cheap Chinese tablet you are stuck with trying to read an LCD screen. Yawn gasp!During the apocalypse she thought it was a good idea to get a subscription to a thing called comixology.. which in and of itself is a great app but realizing how poor it displays on the Kindle.. was beyond disappointingI felt like I was at my grandma's house in 1982 watching the black and white TV in the back room cuz they didn't want me breathing in all the ciggye smoke.In many ways it helped me reminisce of how far we've come along in our society.  This thing would have been so cool in 1990 along with the other LCD video games that were around like game boy or whatever else..I have to admit the only Superior thing to this product is that it had a backlight which you would have to purchase in the 90s for your LCD powered productsbut this has it in spades every time you change the page it flashes the color of the original page during dark mode so it blinds you slightly.. so you can look for your text on the next screen blind.This feature really helped me get to sleep at night time after I blasted my eyes through 30 pages of a really boring book.After wearing sunglasses to bed I felt that it was a more easy way to enjoy my Kindle paper backI wanted to give it more stars I was super excited it pretty much ruined my whole entire day expectation loss of excitement pretty much ruined my whole day and part of the next.Fortunately for me I have Amazon Prime so I just wasted a bunch more money on some other crappy device from another crappy manufacturer that I'll probably also be unhappy with but you know that's how it is nowadaysThanks o bama

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Annoying
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: This is my 3rd Kindle. For the first time I am disappointed. I don't know if it's the material or that's it's so lightweight, but I can't move it around in one hand without it slipping around. A LOT.  It feels really fragile, probably a trade-off to being so lightweight. I'd rather have a bit more weight than these issues, which I didn't have with the previous versions that I didn't think were too heavy. My previous Kindle bought in 2016 had the power button on the back, top right corner. I could turn it on easily with one hand. This bottom button requires me to use two hands or brace it against my body. I don't like the thin sides. They are narrower than my thumbs, and I have small hands, so I can't comfortably grip it on the side. I also don't like the recessed screen. I miss my page turn buttons on the side, which allowed me to turn the page without moving my hand, and go to the previous page without setting it down or having to use two hands. I also don't like having to tap twice to get to the brightness screen, and then not be able to see the print when I'm changing it, to see how bright is necessary. The amount of brightness showing on a mostly blank settings page is different than with a full page of print. So I have to go back and forth to adjust it several times, holding it with two hands because if my thumb is off the side it will fall out of my hand. These things seem nitpicky, but when you're holding a baby, they matter! I don't want to be frustrated picking up my Kindle (slips out of my grip), holding it (side too small), turning it on (can't do one handed), and turning pages (no side buttons). Basically every aspect of this Kindle is annoying me. I'll use it, because it's amazingly convenient compared to an actual book, but as far as Kindles go, it's a huge disappointment. I'd give it a one star but I like the dark mode option, so I'll give it two.

title: Could be so much more than it is
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: This e reader could be one of the best (if Amazon gets the bugs fixed 1st), but I believe that customer feedback is more important , as we are tue cunsumers. I cannot see why anyone would want to have ads pop-up on an e reader, when it is, after all a book. To be interrupted on a regular basis to have to view advertisements. And I have to add that charging $20 to have them removed is pretty low. The older Kindels were the best I have ever encountered & lasted forever without fail. The setup for this readeris messy and awkward, with slides & left arrows are mentioned, yet not on many screens. As for the dark mode, it isn't even close. The only way you can call it dark mode is if the background is totally black; not gray, not dark gray. White font will not show easily & you will end up with eye strain. It is totally easy to accomplish this; the previous Kindle fire was supurb in dark mode.  As for loading books you think we might like should be eliminated; it takes up space for books we do want, & is annoying to have to address them to get them off. This is not a magazine; it is a place to relax & read in peace. I am also worried about not being able to order ebooks from the net or our computers; this may be a red flag for a lot of us. It seems there is more to UNDO than there is TO DO. Please listen to us; I really want to see this reader as user-friendly  as I know it can be.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: New interface is too awful for me to use; I will carry a power bank & stick with Voyage
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I didn't really want to replace my Kindle Voyage, which has worked very well for me for many years, but its battery is no longer fully reliable and it crashed (required reboot) a few times on my last trip so I was complaining about it. The new 2022 Kindle was a gift from my husband who heard my grumbling from the adjacent seat.Today, I opened the box and powered on the Kindle 2022, only to discover some hateful interface designer thinks ENORMOUS thumbnail images are better than seeing more list items on a single page. I disagree, and will not keep this device if it prioritizes images over words, and showing more Amazon sales prompts over making reading a seamless, pleasant experience.I use my Kindle every day, and often for hours at a time. If the interface is bad, I'll carry a power bank and stick with my old Voyage if I can't find somewhere online to get a battery replacement (or a new-to-me additional Voyage in better condition.)I can't evaluate the Battery Life for this review as I don't think I'll have this device long enough to discover whether the hardware itself is any good.The touchscreen seems responsive, but I was very reluctant to give up my physical page turn buttons for this new model anyway, so I'm not the best judge for this feature.I was so excited by this gift, and now I'm utterly disappointed. My husband found people online discussing how to jailbreak the device to go back to old software. I don't want to do that. Amazon has done enough things right with the Kindle reading ecosystem that I was willing to stick with it. If they move away from e-readers as devices FOR PEOPLE WHO LOVE WORDS, they will lose my e-book business.Everyone who hates the new list interface must visit customer service and report it. Hopefully someone will listen. Keep the people who love pictures designing book covers, and ask actual readers what they value in a "List View" of their library. I'd guess most of us prefer to see the TITLE and AUTHOR in a clear font, ideally with an adjustable size as we can do inside the book reading view.Personally, I want to view as many titles per page as possible in my chosen font size! Seeing four titles per page makes it more difficult to find what I want if I'm browsing by flicking through the list, and it doesn't even allow me to see just those volumes I'm actively reading at one time. (I tend to keep 5-6 books in active rotation at any given time.)Epic fail on the latest Kindle interface.

title: It's a very small device
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I enjoy the compactness and portability of Kindle Readers. However, this is a small device and is difficult to use at times. The print can be enlarged, but not the home page which offers books too small to read without a magnifying lens. For my small old fingers, holding and touching the screen to move pages often cause pages to turn when I'm not wanting them to, calls up the settings unexpectedly or can't get them to respond at all, slips between fingers, and sometimes when turning pages a bright white page will flash before returning to the dark mode setting. It takes two hands to use and while it's easy to read the print in bed, it's too small to be propped to rest on one's side and use only one hand. I'm getting a cover, hoping it will help to hold it. If that doesn't work that perhaps a pop grip will work.  So, meh. I prefer my original Kindle Reader, though I like this back lit reader.

text: Pros:-Lightweight-Customer service is awesome. So awesome that after I posted my first review (this is my second) Amazon called me within 20 minutes of clicking send.-Super long battery life.Cons.-Painfully slow and underpowered by todays standards.-Too short. This unit should have the same proportions as a paperback. The screen should be at least 6√ó8.-Not enough memory. 32 gigs would be better if you store work related manuals and text references on it.-No speaker. It needs at least one speaker, and page turning sound effects, to fully give you the book reading experience of autonomous sensory meridian response you get with reading physical books.-The device is only worth about $35 as is.-Consider downloading the Kindle app to your phone for a better reading experience.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Cannot play games
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I think my biggest problem with the newer versions of Kindle is that you can no longer play games.  We would always have a few on our old Kindle Touch for taking a break from reading or killing time if we were waiting somewhere.  That being said, as an e-reader, it is much clearer to read with better resolution and I do love the dark mode.  Interface-wise, I would have liked to combine list view with collections instead of an either/or, but maybe I just need to play with it more.  However, this was much easier in older models so making it less intuitive seems like a step backwards to me.  Being smaller & lighter but with the same screen size is definitely a plus.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: In general a downgrade from previous model.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Liked the light weight and size of device but too wide to hold comfortably in one hand. I ordered a case so I would have something to hold onto more easily but couldn't find the size information of this model easily and ended up ordering the wrong size case. Quality of print not good compared to previous older Kindle I owned. Also, screen jumped randomly forward in the book and not easy to tell where I was. Had to swipe back a page at a time until I finally recognized where I should be. No logical indicators at bottom of screen to tell where in the book you were. Hightlighting is a real downgrade. Also, font size not as adjustable as my older Kindle. All in all, not a good reading experience! If I had never had a Kindle before, I might have like this better. I wanted something I could read in bright light (which is not good on my phone), but couldn't get past all these things that seemed like downgrades from my old Kindle. If it hadn't died, I would still be using it. I returned the device and case and I went back to reading the Kindle app on my phone and found it eliminated all the things I didn't like about this model except the reading in bright light problem. Maybe when I can afford it, I'll try again with a better Paperwhite.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Be aware! there is no color whatsoever. Black, white & gray -- reminds me of my first TV in 1949
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I know the trend in tech is smaller, lighter and greater resolution, but I didn't realize what impact the return to B&W would have on me. I felt let down, disappointed and a little bit angry that Amazon would expect me to give up so much of my Kindle reading pleasure just to have a more compact, lighter e-reader.Instantly, looking at my library, I felt like there was something wrong with my vision. I had been so used to seeing "my" books in full color. I plugged doggedly on, hoping that it would grow on me, but my revulsion at black on gray "highlighting" (really dimming) was almost visceral.I do light reading sometimes, but more often I read serious books, and really study them. My highlighting habits are a sort of dialog with myself, my education, and the author. The four colors of highlighting are useful for finding a passage again, or for a quick review when I've been away from a book for a while.I am grateful to Amazon for free returns, and used the opportunity to let "them" know how disappointed I was in the tradeoff from "the old Kindle" to this new form factor.Before you buy, ask yourself how important the color features (especially highlighting) are to you on your current Kindle. Better to wait until color e-ink is available, in my opinion.

title: Too small, frustrating controls.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: So far it's nothing like the original, easy-to-use, easy-to-read Kindle.  (If I could have found a refurbished original, I would have bought it in a heartbeat.)  It's a small device that has many mysterious touch and swipe controls that you must remember, and you almost can't help touching the touchscreen when you handle it - which then takes unwanted actions because you touched it.  The screen lets you read half a page at a time, which is like reading it on my phone.  I'm not sure I'm going to keep it, but I don't want to pay $300 for a more user-friendly Kindle, either.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: More than one problem with this!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: It often skips a page--or more--when touching either back or forward. I won't waste my time contacting Amazon about this. Others have done so, received a replacement, and had the same problem.Also, the plastic housing is too narrow on the top and sides, making it difficult to keep from touching the screen and having the page go back or forward, plus getting some option other than the book I am reading.EDIT: I HATE THIS THING! It is non-responsive when touching a lot of the "buttons." And you must have WiFi connected even to DELETE a book.I have a much older Kindle (Generation 4, I think) with physical page-turn buttons on both sides. With this, I have to charge the battery every day, but I much prefer it to these "touch screen" things. And yeah, Amazon has a very expensive Kindle with page-turn buttons, but they are on the right side. Doesn't work for me because I read in bed lying on my left side...even if I would pay the high price.BTW, what's with all the "Generation" labels that I can never figure out? Can't they just use a model number?

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Too lightweight and flimsy feeling, impractical bezels!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: The screen is a delight on this new Kindle, and it was the only thing that made me slightly regretful about sending it back. At 300 dpi it‚Äôs nice and sharp. It also has the ability to reverse black and white if you like that. And I love a recessed screen on an ereader‚Ä¶ it seems like it‚Äôs even more glare-free than the waterproof version.BUT the cons far outweighed the pros for me. This Kindle is so lightweight that it feels like it might fly out of your hand at the least movement. The back isn‚Äôt grippy at all, making the problem worse. I realize now that an ereader needs to have just a *little* bit of heft to it so that it stays put in your hand.And the newly reduced bezels are now so tiny that my thumbs could never really find a comfortable spot to rest, meaning I was constantly fidgeting. I couldn‚Äôt settle into reading (as I do on my older Paperwhite) because I simply couldn‚Äôt get comfortable.My solution‚Ä¶ return this Kindle, and go for an older refurbished Paperwhite. The ideal ereader for me!

title: New User Interface is a disaster
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: Note to Amazon developers:  An e-reader is not a phone!  An e-reader is not a tablet!  E-ink is not an LED!The new user interface is a disaster from my perspective.  The list view of books now shows a pointless and almost illegible picture of the book cover.  The picture takes up space and there are only four books shown on the screen.  I called Amazon and there is no way to turn this off. The list view is now one long page instead of being multiple pages as it was before.  There's a scroll bar now to move through the list, but it doesn't really work.  The response of e-ink is slow so you can't see where you are while you're scrolling.  There's no option to go ahead one screen.  So finding a specific place or scrolling through the list without missing anything is next to impossible.  There is a search bar, but it's less convenient than old way., This interface reminds me of the first Kindles which also made having many books difficult.  I returned it and bought new previous generation Paperwhite with 6" screen on Ebay since this new Kindle is Amazon's only 6" option.

title: Cover Screens Are Terrible
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 30, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I bought this unit to replace my 2017 Kindle.  Nothing wrong with the old unit, I just wanted something newer.  Big Mistake.Amazon has totally changed the menu system, and in my opinion for the worse.  Instead of a simple text-based system the menus now show book covers.  And there is only one line of covers for books I have bought, and multiple lines of books Amazon is trying to sell me.Further, under the old system I could remove a book from the Kindle and keep it in the cloud.  Now, if I 'delete the download' the book cover remains on the Kindle taking up space.  If I want to delete the cover I have to delete the book from the cloud which means if I ever want to go back to the book I have to buy it again.  Why, Amazon, WHY?Amazon, you took something simple, functional, and beautiful and turned it into yet another ugly, confusing marketing scheme.  I still have not found a good explanation of the difference between the "Home" and "Library" sections....I haven't decided whether to return the Kindle.  If there is a way to return to the old menu style, please tell me.  I will be a happy customer then.January 2023 Update: I continue to dislike the new menu system.  It seems to be all about proposing new titles AND, above all, saving web space.  In the old system if I bought a book I downloaded it, read it, then deleted from kindle.  However, upon deleting from Kindle a copy of the book was kept in my cloud account.  Now, that copy is no longer saved and should I want to re-read the book I would have to buy it again.  Great marketing strategy but as usual the customer is the one who loses.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Confusing and frustrating to set up
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 25, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I bought two for my parents. This device was not made with the user in mind at all. The setup process took a full hour and a half. It was confusing and directionless. I had to create a kindle account then an Amazon account then connect the Amazon account to the kindle account then some random thing called ‚Äúgood reads‚Äù popped up and needed to have an account. Then we couldn‚Äôt get going on anything without adding a credit card. Then at the end we couldn‚Äôt figure out where to even purchase a Kindle Unlimited subscription. We spent thirty minutes on the kindle app trying to figure out why we we only could download ‚Äúsamples‚Äù of books only to realize that we can only buy books off Amazon. This is insanely convoluted and not intuitive. I am beyond frustrated. My parents are unlikely to use these devices if they have to switch between multiple apps just to find a book.

title: DO NOT PAY TO REMOVE ADS UP FRONT
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 2, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I paid for ads to be removed when purchasing the device initially. When I activated the device, it came with ads, though I was charged the extra fee up front. When checking my Amazon account, I could see that though the fee had been invoiced and paid, "Special Offers" had not been removed and I was prompted to pay an additional fee to get rid of ads. When calling customer support, they initially told me that it was not possible to remove ads, then offered a refund, then after 1 hour finally disabled the ads on my device. I hope my experience using the device isn't as bad as this experience trying to simply get what I rightly paid for. I recommend removing ads after receiving your device to ensure proper activation and to save an hour of your time troubleshooting with customer support.

text: The only positive about this Kindle is the battery life - I can read all day and more without multiple charges. Otherwise, I hate it. title: I wanted to love this. Would work great for basic reading
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 4, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I wanted to love this. I got it to read on. Several things that were deal breakers for me -‚Ä¢It was clunky loading right off the bat brand new. The screen flashed with almost every action‚Ä¢No navigation buttons. This results in touching around the screen‚Ä¢No apps except kindle built in. It does have a browser but it would not load even on good WIFI.‚Ä¢How drawn out it is to send books to the Kindle from my library's Libby app.  It didn't register that I had Kindle unlimited so I had to do this extra step to read for free.‚Ä¢The ads on the lock screen - now note, I knew about this when I bought it. It is worth spending the extra $20 to upgrade to your own book showing on the screen . However it's obnoxious that they charge for this feature. You're already sinking $100 + into a device. Why not just include it as a thank you?‚Ä¢Over sensitive light adjustment. I think this may be why the screen flashed so often -over compensating/adjusting for the light around me‚Ä¢Only Wifi. It wasn't very clear that it only came with WIFI but I should have read the fine print.Pros:This would work well if you don't mind the slower OS and just want the basic reading cabilities on it. The battery life is fantastic! It does have good storage on it.

If a separate case needs to be purchased, this Kindle is no longer a good value, and will no longer be lightweight.  I probably won't purchase another, probably won't recommend it to family and friends.  The textured case was perfect for me.  (The previous one died in less than 2 years.  I'm no longer convinced Kindle is the brand for me.)

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: This is the worst kindle I‚Äôve ever had.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 23, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: My husband got me this kindle for my birthday this is the 3rd kindle I‚Äôve had in my life time. I‚Äôm so beyond disappointed. I‚Äôll start with positives because it‚Äôs a shorter list, it‚Äôs light weight, the swiping features/dark mode are nice, and just like that we have concluded the positives. I wish it had more length because when you go to turn the pages I seem to be always toggling the settings a lot more than actually turning the page. I had one of the very first kindles with keyboards and even back then the whole point of a kindle was that it dimmed and brightened to fit your environment without disrupting your reading experience. The page refresh and how you can see words on the previous page and options you‚Äôve selected is atrocious (other commenters are calling it screen burn) if you read fan fiction on your kindle this is not the kindle for you the screen burn/refresh issue makes it a jumbled mess of the pages and you cant read anything. I can‚Äôt believe Amazon has put a product out like this. I will be returning this and getting a real kindle because this isn‚Äôt one. I don‚Äôt normally review items but i needed the community to understand how awful this product is if you‚Äôre expecting a real kindle. I will say that if all you do is read real books it‚Äôs not too bad, it doesn‚Äôt do the sunscreen burn in them. Not dimming automatically is a huge deal breaker for me I‚Äôve discovered. Hope this was helpful. Happy reading.

title: Updated: now it's back to Very Disappointing
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I had downgraded my disappointment, but now I'm more disappointed than ever, because it seems that either the kindle I received is malfunctioning and won't let me change the fonts of certain books, or there are just some books that don't allow you to change the font. As someone with both dyslexia and migraines, this is an absolute deal breaker. I just now gave myself a horrible headache after reading a few pages in this terrible font, and then I made it worse by spending too much time trying to fix the font with no success.Add that to the fact that the screen is too small and the entire thing is too lightweight to hold comfortable in your hand (I constantly feel like I'm going to drop it) this model of kindle is an incredible let down. The size of screen is important because if the font is too small it's hard to read and if it's too big I have to turn the page every 20 seconds given how fast I read. It's very annoying. Don't even get me started on having to scroll through my "library" of books covers with miniscule print that I can't read without clicking on it, and I will never stop being salty about the fact that basic kindles no longer have page turn buttons.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: I found it difficult to use
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I found the whole kindle concept too expensive. Why get locked into a system that costs extra for monthly charges after spending too much for the very limited system. The Fire HD 8 plus is far better system and much more feature rich. The versatility power and almost unlimited choices makes for a better choice. It does however tend to have a steep learning curve because of all it can do.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: This is my 6th Kindle purchase.  Very disappointing on this particular model
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I was really looking forward to this new Kindle because I would be able to read at night without disturbing anyone.  The lighted feature is its best feature.  This product was advertised as a 2022 model; not a reconditioned product.It often goes to a white blank page and must be rebooted.  The battery life is much more difficult to maintain than other Kindles I have had.  When I re-open a book, often times I receive a message that the application I am trying to access failed before it actually opens the book.To say I am disappointed in this model is minimal at best.  I am very surprised because I purchased other kindles that have been advertised as reconditioned and they have been a good product lasting several years.  This 2022 product is very disappointing.  I do not recommend it at all.

text: I will try to be succinct.  I kept my new Amazon Paperwhite in its case.  I opened it on our South America cruise. So, here I am in the South Pacific with 20 wonderful books I can't read because  I CANT CHARGE THE STUPID UNIT!!!!  I called on the ship's phone to Kindle support, explained my problem, was asked to hold, and the person never returned to help me figure out a solution.  I spent a day in a taxi trying to buy a new Kindle, but of course it is not carried in stores.So here I sit on a ship for a month with nothing to read!

text: I don't leave reviews often, but I was very excited to purchase this Kindle. I had the original Kindle when it came out over 10 years ago.  I loved it and used it often.  I eventually got a tablet version of the Kindle and used 2 different versions. Now when I found out this Kindle was released I was ready to go back to the basics where I could use the Kindle even outside in the sun. I love that the screen is also back lit for reading in darker rooms. The battery seems decent and it came with a C charger. It is super convenient and lightweight as well. I am very happy with my purchase.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Not ready for Prime Time -- Writing Features Are No Good or Nonexistent ("Coming Soon" says Amazon)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 30, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: According to Amazon Hype it's always "coming soon": Kindle Scribe "will add lasso select tools, improved notebook organization and navigation, and the ability to send documents to Kindle Scribe directly from within Microsoft Word (Microsoft 365 subscription required)."  It's the end of March (4 months later) and it is still not here. It's a good enough ereader, that is slightly awkward to hold. As a notetaker (especially for working on PDFs) it's no good and does not compare to the leaders like Remarkable 2 and other polished e-ink tablets.  Furthermore, although it is light and its screen size overall is good, it's not as easy as the better color e-ink tablets for working with as a note taking/writing implement that can sync streaming of notes. Nor does it provide a good handwriting experience on a screen. It does not provide a paper writing like experience; it's just another computer pen (and not the best) for writing on a glass screen.

title: Fantastic Upgrades on Kindle Basic
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Without Lockscreen Ads
text: I‚Äôve acquired several Kindles throughout the years. I was excited to see this model coming out, because I feel that the Kindle Basic has long since needed an upgrade. I purchased this to be my on-the-go Kindle to stay in my bag with me, as my previous Kindle Basic recently met it‚Äôs untimely demise. I‚Äôm shocked to see that the overall reviews aren‚Äôt higher, and I personally feel that the individuals who rated it lowly, just didn‚Äôt read the description and had unrealistic expectations. This is a (VERY!) lightweight Kindle. It is significantly smaller than the Paperwhite or the Oasis and weighs a lot less. It fits in my work bag and purse easily. The screen does has bevels, but I personally like those. It now has Dark Mode, which is a huge upgrade in my opinion. The pages turn a lot faster than the previous models. All in all, I am very happy with this Kindle. It is a fantastic option to those interested in reading on a device, who don‚Äôt want to spend more for one of the other models. Only critique, I wish Amazon would bring back the white Kindles!

Also I wish they would make the back of the kindle rubberized like the Paperwhite, just feels better to hold and less scratchy.

title: Barely usable device
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I have one of the original Paperwhites that were offered at half the price. My Kindle Paperwhite is barely usable. All of the damn People magazines published since the Paperwhite came out are impossible to remove. I can't get to the books I want to read without a lot of patience while wading through all those issues. The scroll-down in the Library freezes. It takes 30 minutes to open another book. If I accidently touch the screen while reading a book, the story skips backward or forward 3 or 4 pages. Sometimes, it goes to the beginning. The Table of Contents doesn't like to scroll once you get to the bottom of the list on the first page. If I'm on Chapter 42 and the bottom TOC page is at Chapter 39, I can't get it to move at all. I just take a guess at the location and keep using the location finder to get close to where I need to get back to when I was thrown off. Then, I page forward page by page to find where I was reading. Today, I tried to use a link at the end of a book to order the next book in the series. When it got to Amazon, the typeface was too small to read. It refused to be resized. It got too big and then back to too small. I finally got out a magnifier and typed in my name and password. It kept telling me that my password was incorrect. I'm doing this review on my phone. The convenience of a smaller reader is not worth the navigation aggravation.

For instance, when I wanted to re-read Devoted in Death by JD Robb, the paperwhite couldn't find it.  It told me the date I purchased it, but claimed it wasn't in my library.  I solved the problem by locating it on my Kindle 3, clicked on it, and it was available to read.The kindle 3 lists all the books in my library, 10 to a page. text: I guess technically it‚Äôs a downgrade since I am trading in a 2015 Paperwhite and going with the basic kindle.  I love it so far. Dark mode is the best thing ever! It remembers my dark mode setting so once I hit dark mode, it adjusts back to that setting automatically. (On regular mode, I have it at 17, on dark mode I have it at 7.)It‚Äôs SUPER light and feels like you‚Äôre holding nothing. The cover I got doesn‚Äôt add much weight so it‚Äôs very comfortable to hold for long periods of time.I‚Äôve had it a week and use it at least 45 minutes every day and the battery is at 63%. At this rate it‚Äôll last me about a month between charges which is really awesome.I hesitated to get this model because it is, technically, a downgrade, as I mentioned but I feel like I upgraded because the features that enticed me to get the paperwhite all those years ago are present in this model. product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: 11th Gen Kindle, some big upgrades from 2019 version
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 12, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: This 11th Generation of the Kindle eReader comes with a few big upgrades over the previous version:-SCREEN: New HD screen has 300ppi (Pixels Per Inch), compared to 167ppi in previous version (2019)-STORAGE: 16GB storage space, compared to 8GB in previous version-BATTERY: Now can charge to full with 9W charging in 2 hours, compared to 4 hours with 5W charging in previous version.  Battery lasts now up to 6 weeks with 30 min daily use, compared to 4 weeks with same use in previous version. (Actual battery life varies with use)-USB-C: Now using USB-C charging port instead of outdated micro-USB in previous version-SIZE/WEIGHT: Slightly smaller frame although same size screen, slightly lighter compared to previous version (2022 version is 6.2‚Äù x 4.3‚Äù x 0.32‚Äù and 5.56 oz, 2019 version was 6.3‚Äù x 4.5‚Äù x 0.34‚Äù and 6.1 oz)Also, this 11th generation version uses 75% post-consumer recycled plastics in the Black color device, (only 30% in Denim color device).  This percentage of recycled content has been steadily increasing with new Kindle devices.  Last year‚Äôs Paperwhite had 60% post-consumer recycled plastics.Overall, this is a nice upgrade over the last generation of Kindle.  These devices have always been targeted at avid readers that want the most paper-like reading experience, and this newest version adds double the storage space, longer battery life, faster charging options, USB-C and a higher resolution screen.  This regular kindle screen now looks about as good as the Paperwhite version from last year.  (Note that this Kindle screen isn‚Äôt waterproof though, it does NOT have the same IPX8 rating of the Paperwhite)For me, being able to finally use the same USB-C chargers that I use for everything else is a big deal.  Having the same ppi screen resolution as the Paperwhite is also pretty nice.  As a family that reads TONS of eBooks, we will definitely be using a few of these.  When comparing to the previous version, the difference is noticeable right away; if you like the way the 2021 Paperwhite looked, you will probably like this new Kindle also because the screen resolution is almost the same.We are loving these so far.  Sometimes it is nice to have a dedicated reading device, free from other distractions, and without eye-strain problems.  Avid readers know how bad glare and eyestrain can be, so devices like this make a big difference.

title: What happened to Kindl!e?!?! 2nd Update! Final.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: FINAL UPDATE - Thanks Amazon got a full update for this product (and cover and screen glass) Finished reading books with lots of graphs on my old iPad.  Works well enough.  Finished with Kindle.  Quick refund sot there's that!  1st Update below! Original:  Lousy product.  Coming from a 5th Gen Kindle (wanted to keep 'Active Content' capability, so have gone through a few rebuild or reconditioned 5th Gen Kindles that worked - well, OK).  Difficulty these days trying to buy such an old Kindle, so decided to get a new one - 11th Gen - for just reading at a recent good price (and paying $$s for supressing ads!) and found out it's quite lightweight and smaller - about the only thing goods I can say!  When you were reading something (on older Kindles), you could advance pages by a simple swipe of the finger to advance or go back. THIS Kindle, however, seems to want to to jump several pages frequently.  It is often VERY difficult to go back, and then is seems to want to go several pages at a time.  Really a poor product (awkward to use) and could never recommend to anyone.  Maybe Amazon will read this and reach out to me to tell me I should only lightly tap or some new such technique.  I've already tried that, too, to no avail.  No recommendation for this Kindle from this user.  Oh, BTW, the portrayal of a book'sa charts and graphs is horrible - cannot read print (it's very light gray) and though you can expand it, it is very awkward to get a zoomed graph that you can read well - often it will give the graphic, but you cannot see the details of the side and bottom of the chart or graph.  Truly as bad as my 5th Gen Kindles!  Maybe I need to go to reading on my iPad.  This is NOT an improved product! Update, after calls form Cust Support offering return an refund:  Really, REALLY aggravating to use!  Loses the book pages and %-progress after some few page turns.  Also CANNOT get to asterisk-footnotes...all I get are "Wikipedia has no entries." Need to try multiple times to get to the footnote. (I am a 6-footer with pretty large hanbds so the little asterisk is hard to directly hit.) And pages jump all around - goes forward a few, and hard to get it going backwards to get back to where you where reading (aggravated by usually no way to know the exact page or %-progress in book!  And did I say it is VERY lousy/poor trying to read graphs and charts and anything like an illustration.  Grey tones leave any print in lowest resolution of grey! m And I do not need an Amazon CSR calling and offering me to get a Fire or other item.  Bottom Line: Most recent Kindle is a POS! Don't waste your money! SCREWED UP, CRIPPLED PRODUCT!  Who else make a book reader?

text: I am in love with this purchase! I wanted to started reading books again and after a while of thinking about it, I finally decided to get a Kindle after seeing how much my coworker liked hers (Kindle Oasis). When I came on Amazon to go shopping for one, I came across the 2022 11th generation release. It was ($109 without ads) at the time I bought it. I love it! It's my first Kindle. I read almost every day. It's lightweight, the perfect size to hold in your hand and read. The screen is very easy on your eyes so you can read for long periods of time. It's very easy to use and navigate, easy to download books and you can customize the font, lockscreen and pick the type of background you want (Black of White). The battery life is great. I can go long periods of time on one charge and it charges pretty fast. I highly recommend!

title: It's not as nice as an oasis, but it's also not $400
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I'm one of Oprah's besties, so I admit, I've owned 4 kindle oasis' including the TOL model with cell coverage to download books for as long as you own the device it even transfers to whoever owns it. And , LORD HAVE MERCY, those page turn buttons.  I've owned every kindle from the keyboard to the TOL oasis'. I bought a basic kindle and I gotta tell you. I didn't understand or use the warm light correctly, so no loss.32 gigs of storage? Amazon does an amazing job of keeping your books stored on the cloud. So that's no loss. The 7 in screen is nice. But no. I lose shit, everything. Phones, computers, tablets, phones including a folding screen RAZR  i haven't lost it ... Yet. LoL so, $99 I could buy and replace 4 of these for one of those. So. Bottom line. I get a better battery and the same e ink screen. Plus the new one is so light. I wish I could trust myself without a case, but major klutz. The clear case In the photo almost triples the weight of the device. Check how much ithr case weighs. Sorry for rambling. Old age happens to everybody. I take the cass off when I'm at home. When arthritis attacks, weight matters. I give it 5 stars, because, let's face it, it sucks. I read a lot and ifh charge will last me a day and a half. I carry around a battery, it'll fill my kindle almost 10 times.Buy the kindle It has a great feel in your hand and the battery lasts long enough to not be too bitter. I give it 5 stars otherwise. Unless, you're like me and won't be happy until you get one, the oasis price tag is justified, it's machined aluminum a huge battery. I felt like Oprah, walking around the hospital in my gown with an extra one to keep my private parts private, I really felt like a  celebrity walking around the hospital, smoking weed and reading ony oasis.  But if you're not Oprah, then the basic kindle is the shit. Buy without reservations.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Excellent entry level Kindle -- has a hidden bargain for removing the ad-filled screensaver
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2022
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I have two 32GB Kindle Oasis that have several valuable features that this Kindle does not BUT they cost several hundred dollars more. They're great devices but expensive. So I just bought this basic Kindle for carrying around in my purse.The screen is about the same height for both Kindle models but the width of the basic Kindle screen is noticeably narrower than that of the Oasis. The basic Kindle's case is made of mostly recycled plastic and all movement among options are accomplished by sweeping your finger across the screen -- no buttons.Because the case is plastic rather than metal, this basic Kindle weighs about an ounce less which matters when carried around all day. The power button would be better on the top of the Kindle but I am pleased that it uses USB-C rather than the archaic mini-USB that the Oasis still uses. The16GB storage is quite generous and better than the base Paperwhite model. This uses wifi only and doesn't offer a cellular optionI find the basic Kindle's screen remarkably good despite being lit by so few LEDs. The screen is the same 300 ppi as all other Kindles but appears slightly ¬†less crisp because of the basic model's 4 LEDs. I find it easy on my eyes however.I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the ad-filled screensaver can be easily removed FOR FREE (but only if you call in) because the Content and Devices, Devices, page for your Kindle will say the removal is free. Alternatively, rather than paying $20 more to purchase the Kindle without that screensaver, you can call to have it removed for $15.The issue is not the content of the screensaver. It's that any cover with a magnetic closure stops on the ad screensaver but opens directly to the book you were reading with the standard screensaver. I believe that both the free and $15 prices for removal are in error so I would suggest having the ad-filled screensaver removed immediately.I encourage you to accept the free four months of Kindle Unlimited included with current purchases. KU allows you to select (and keep indefinitely) up to 20 items. This is a bargain worth $40 so why leave money on the table?Also for the cash-conscious, other than using those four free months of KU, do use your library card to connect your new Kindle to the Libby app. The app will search for Kindle books at your library and will, after setup, load your library books onto your Kindle. These free books automatically vanish when your lending period is over.You can also save by checking to see if friends or family have an old Kindle they're not using (working or not). Even the oldest Kindle can be traded in for a cash payment (which may be as little as $10) but the trade-in also gives you 20% off your next new Kindle. I have seen certified, refurbished basic Kindles offered at $79  -- but remember that price doesn't include the four months of KU and it may or may not include free removal of ad screensaver so are not the bargain they appear to be.Three items to tweak in Settings. If you open any book, and tap the top of the page and then the Aa, you can select your own default font, font size, and page setup which will be used for everything you read from then on. I use Helvetica with one unit of bold, size 5 or 6. My layout uses the left option for all four choices. In the More tab ¬†in the same area, you can turn off being notified about how many times various passages have been highlighted by other readers. I also suggest that you use Settings, Device Options, and tap on Display Cover so that the screensaver is the cover of the book you're reading and Settings, Device Options, Advanced, Home & Library, to group your books into series.¬†I've had Kindles since the first one offered and am never without one in reach. They allow me to read in small bits anywhere. They're great! I continue to be quite happy with my Oasis for reading at home but think this basic Kindle will be a workhorse for carrying around. The reduced size, weight, and cost make this a buy at $99.NOTE: The one downside for some people will be that this Kindle is not waterproof like the Paperwhite and Oasis. I have taken my Kindles to the beach and the tub without ever getting one wet. BUT, if you are someone who must have waterproof, this isn't it.

title: My first Kindle!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 13, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: I was worried I would hate this. There is such a comforting and nostalgic feeling about holding a book in your hands, and I love collecting. I used to have a collection, but as I started moving around, I discovered a problem... packing and moving around books is a hellish nightmare. I've moved about 6 times in 3 years and I'll be moving again eventually. I didn't want to buy more books and was tired of moving my books halfway across the country, but I've missed reading! So, this was the next best option. A small device to carry all my books. I've donated most of my physical collection and I'm honestly happy I did. The Kindle is very lightweight and easy to hold. Perfect for reading at night which I often do. And the battery life is suspiciously good. My only issue is that clicking around the menu and library seems a bit slow to the electronics we are used to in our everyday life. But honestly, it's not that big of a deal. I even got the version with ads and I barely notice them. In fact they have suggested some good books. This has been a purchase I won't regret. And I'll appreciate it the next time I move, lmao.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: My "Goldilocks" Kindle
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 7, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: So, it's been a decade-plus: my stalwart Kindle Keyboard was finally giving up the proverbial ghost; Amazon was phasing out its 3G network for Kindle (because bye-bye 3G in general). The lack of built-in front-lighting had been bugging me for a while (and the Amazon-made cover with pull-out light was fair-to-middling at best), so it was clearly time for a replacement. The Oasis was, to me, needlessly expensive: a metal casing that was both cold to the touch (bad) and prone to scratches/dents/Et Cetera (worse); the Paperwhite Signature Edition seemed nice, but (1) was also pricey, (2) had almost too much storage at 32GB (whereas the 8GB "standard" Paperwhite was too little, and probably due for a product refresh anyway), and (3) that flush, "bezelless" screen‚Ä¶that would seem fabulous, right up to the moment you drop the thing and slide it, face-down, over something even mildly abrasive. And it's still a tad big, albeit smaller than my old Kindle.But: Amazon decided to upgrade the "basic" Kindle, simultaneously upping both the screen resolution (achieving essential parity with the Paperwhite) *and* storage capacity to a "just-right" 16GB. Combine this with a near-universally-pocketable size, while still offering a reasonably-sized 6" screen, good front-lighting (yes, four lights, one for each side, is enough‚Ä¶I'm more concerned about evenness of illumination than sheer intensity, which in this case is also adequate to my eyes), and light weight, and I was sold. Yes, I paid for the "privilege" of not dealing with ads; yes, I *know* the ads are seen only on the lockscreen (and supposedly only relate to book "recommendations", but couldn't confirm that last bit). But  since I plan to keep this for hopefully as long as I did my old Kindle, I'd just as soon not deal with any of that, and decided I could deal with the $20 "payoff", if you will. The bottom line here is that you won't be missing much by choosing this Kindle over the pricier stuff (including the Scribe, unless you're into that sort of thing‚Ä¶). The smaller size of this Kindle is *very* much a plus, encouraging you to take it with you even if you have nothing more than an overcoat pocket to carry it in, because it'll most likely fit, and easily at that. Seriously recommended.

product_name: Kindle (2022 release) ‚Äì The lightest and most compact Kindle, now with a 6‚Äù 300 ppi high-resolution display, and 2x the storage - Black
title: Infuriating: Kindle 11 plug-in wire does not fit or work with Kindle 10
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited | Offer Type: Lockscreen Ad-Supported
text: How could you do this? First you figured out how to avoid allowing Apple iPhone users to plug in their Kindles with the same power source wiring by refusing to shape Kindle's plug-in end to match Apple's. Now you multiply that offense by coming out with a new design for the plug-in end of your own Kindle 11 so that it won't work with your Kindle 10s. Result: most of us will have to maintain three sets of wires to run all three devices. Why did you do it this way? Profit-seeking? What else?  I can only suggest that you be careful crossing streets and do your best to keep out of sight of your customers. You now have me searching for an alternative e-phone -- something I never ever imagined doing.
